text: Superimposed title comes in which reads: Greater New York has a population of 7,434,346, among the least important of whom is......
Hand runs down telephone book page and stops at: John H. Mason - Atty. 258 Broadway

Pedestrian and vehicle traffic crowd the street in front the office building. CAMERA CENTERS on one figure in the crowd, Johnny, who walks slowly along the sidewalk gazing steadily at something he carries in his hands. CAMERA MOV DOWN AND SHOOTS OVER JOHNNY'S SHOULDER at what he is gazi at. It is a large photograph of Jane. CAMERA MOVES BACK T MEDIUM SHOT as Johnny continues on his way, still absorbe in the picture. A vicious bump from a passer-by yanks Joh back from dream realms to the work-a-day world.

(murmuring an apology) Sorry! The passer-by has disappeared into the crowd. Johnny is a to go on, suddenly realizes he is in front of his office building, quickly puts the photograph in his brief case a enters the building.
He starts down the Arcade toward the elevators. A middle- aged man greets him in passing.
"Morning, Mr. Mason.
(cheerily) Good morning! A young lady is next to throw him a greeting.
Hello, Johnny.
Lovely morning! A third greeting comes from a young man about his own age
Hi, Johnny!

Beautiful morning! By now he has reached an open elevator which is filling w people. The door of the elevator next to it opens and sta to discharge its passengers. A starter is stationed betwe the two elevators. A definite reaction from the starter a he sees Johnny. Johnny is about to enter the first elevat then, seeing that the second one is empty, starts toward He finds his way barred by the starter who warmly grips h hand.
"Morning, Mr. Mason.
Harry, it's a marvelous morning! The starter has one hand behind his back. He is violently gesturing a signal to the operator of the second elevator
Have a good trip?
Sensational!
Great city, Boston!
Terrific!
He gets the pantomimed signal of the starter, bangs the d shut, and his elevator starts upward.

The starter is shoving Johnny back to the first elevator. Johnny manages to hand starter a cigar as he enters the elevator. The elevator is now full, and the operator wait for the signal to start. The starter looks toward the dia of the second elevator.
The second elevator is approaching the tenth floor and continuing up.
The starter gives the signal. The door closes, the elevat starts up.
The door opens, and several passengers emerge, including Johnny.
All the personnel of the law firm -- clerks, stenographer telephone girl -- are lined up watching the door.
He stands against the wall clutching a string which runs upward from his hand. CAMERA PANS to take in the entrance door. We see the knob turn.
He yanks the string.

It has opened; and as Johnny enters, a contraption arrang over the door opens; and Johnny is showered with rice an old shoes. There are whoops and shrieks from off scene. O voice starts singing: "Happy Bridegroom, yoo-hoo" to tune вЂњHappy Birthday" and others join in.
Johnny looking on bewilderedly while the office personnel sings.

(singing) Happy Bridegroom, yoo-hoo! Happy Bridegroom, yoo-hoo! Happy Bridegroom, Happy Bridegroom, Happy Bridegroom, yoo-hoo! The song ends with laughter and ad lib chatter as Johnny' office mates surround him, pumping his hand, whacking his back, congratulating or razzing him, according to their m

A business trip. Huh?... Where's the little woman, Johnny -- why didn't you bring her along?... Is she one of the Lodges or one of the Cabots?... What's she got that I haven't got?... You'd better be careful with your expense account -- no extras now!... That's what you get for going out of town!... You old bluebeard, you!... I'm going to sue you for breach of promise!... Today our Johnny is a man!...
Johnny, what's she like?

Now wait a minute! I can't describe her -- nobody could. But it just so happens I've got a picture of her. He opens up his brief case and produces the photograph previously established. It is snatched out of his hand by one of the clerks who rushes out of the scene with it. Th others rush after him. A chorus of whistles, screams and  other extravagant reactions.

Excited and thrilled at the sensation caused by the mere photograph of his bride, but trying not to show it. Carte comes into Shot, carrying a batch of legal papers. He is type who has had but one love affair in all his life -- himself.
Well, well, well!
Hello, Carter.
So you combined pleasure with business! Wait till Judge Doolittle hears about this, my boy!
Hears about what?
About your getting married on his time -- and without his consent -- (significantly) Or his daughter's.
Well, what's she got to do about it?
(smirking) Well, now, my boy -- the favorite topic of conversation around these parts has been that you and Miss Doolittle --
Aw, Malarkey! Office talk, Carter. Isn't a word of truth in it!
Judge Doolittle may not think so.
(fiercely)  Is that so? Well, if he doesn't like it, he can lump it. Before he can finish, the rest of the staff come into the scene, following the clerk holding the photograph.

(as clerk returns photograph) You never asked me for my picture, Johnny. When's the next train leave for Boston?... Aren't I as pretty as that?... Johnny, has she got a sister?... No wonder we couldn't compete... I want one of them too!... I wish the boss'd send me out of town!... Never knew you had it in you, Johnny!...
Suddenly there is a melting away of the group around John as the clerks start for their cubicles and the stenos ret to their desks and make a great show of being busy.
He is suddenly alone -- the photograph of his new bride clutched in his hand.
Mason! Johnny turns, registers consternation.
Oh, good morning, Judge Doolittle!

Judge Doolittle has entered and stands, frowning, in the midst of rice and old shoes. He's a formidable old codger who has terrified many a witness. Doolittle is somewhat d and wears an acousticon arrangement to facilitate his hea He has a habit of speaking in a very low voice, while all his employees have been trained to raise their voices in talking to him. Throughout the entire scene between Dooli and Johnny, Doolittle will speak in a low voice and Johnn will speak loudly, almost shouting at times.
What's all this mess? CAMERA PANS him up to Johnny. Johnny takes off his hat.
Ah -- Well, it seems everybody around here found out that I -- er -- I -- while I was in Boston --
What were you doing in Boston?
Why, you sent me sir. Don't you remember you sent me up there to get a deposition on the Higgins versus Higgins case!
Did you get it?
Yes, sir.
Well, what's all this? What's all this horseplay about?
Well, while I was in Boston, after I got the deposition I had a few hours to spare and so I -- just a few hours -- and I --
Go on! Go on!
(gulps) I got married!
(sharply) You WHAT?
(shouts)  I got married.
(as if he hadn't heard right) You got married?
Yes, sir. I got married.
Come into my office!
Yes, sir. CAMERA PANS with him as he strides toward his office, fol by Johnny. It somehow resembles a march to the guillotine

head_text.subj: CLERKS AND STENOGRAPHERS LOOKING AFTER THEM -
AT DOOR OF DOOLITTLE'S PRIVATE OFFICE

text: Doolittle enters with Johnny.
at door of his office. He stares towards Doolittle's offi with a smirk on his face; dry-washes his hands and exits into his office.

On the wall behind the desk are two paintings. One of Jud Doolittle in his magisterial robes and the other of Chief Justice Hughes of the United States, in his robes. Doolit is seated at his desk glaring at Johnny who stands facing him like a prisoner at the bar. Johnny has the brief case one hand and the framed picture of Jane in the other.
Where's the deposition? Johnny lays Jane's photograph on the desk as he opens the brief case and takes the deposition from it, which he han folded, to Doolittle.
There you are, sir. As Doolittle opens up the paper to look at it, a letter f out.
Inside a large, hand-drawn heart, which covers the page o note paper, is written: To the party of the first part: I love you. (signed) Part of the second part.
As Doolittle picks up the letter.
What's this?

(very much embarrassed) Oh, that's -- that's just sort of a letter. Doolittle hands it back. Johnny stuffs the letter into hi pocket with increasing embarrassment. Doolittle adjusts h glasses and starts to read the deposition. He addresses J without looking up.
So you got married?
Yes, sir. Doolittle looks up and glances significantly at a framed picture on his desk.
It is a photograph of Doolittle's daughter and upon it is written: "To Father, with love, Eunice."
I imagine this will be a surprise to  some people.

Yes, sir! (catches himself as he realizes the significance of Doolittle's glance at the picture of his daughter) No, sir! I mean -- well -- I don't know. It all happened rather suddenly. You see, we met on Boston Common the night I arrived, and I'd had a bite at Thompson's Spa -- and then I took a little stroll around the Common and -- and I saw her standing there -- she was just standing there -- she had a cinder in her eye. Doolittle looks up suddenly from reading the deposition.
Where?
In her eye.
Whose eye?
Jane -- Mrs. Mason -- my wife.
Oh.
Of course, she wasn't my wife then -- she's my wife now, though. And I got the cinder out of her eye and --
And you married her.
Yes, sir.
Quick work, wasn't it?
Yes, sir. Oh Judge, we knew -- we knew the minute we looked at each other -- we knew -- we knew the minute we looked at each other.
You did!
Yes, sir.
Last year there were nearly a half a million divorces in this country. Congratulations, Mason!
Thank you very much, sir. An office boy comes in with papers he puts on Doolittle's desk.

Mr. Hutch would like your opinion on this, sir. (he starts out, and as he passes Johnny, hands him a letter) Oh, this is for you, Mr. Mason... special messenger. It's marked "Rush - Important." (exits) Johnny takes the letter, glances at the envelope, registe delight. Then, aware of Doolittle's eyes fixed on him, he hastily puts the letter in his pocket.
(glancing up from papers office boy brought in) Rush? Important? What is it?
Oh, it's nothing.
(severely) What is it?
Oh -- it's a letter from my wife.
Your wife? What did you do -- leave her in Boston?
Oh, no. She's right here, sir.
Here -- in town?
Yes, sir.
(the great cross- examiner) If your wife's in town, why did she write you a letter?

Well, she likes to write letters, Judge. Yes, it's a sort of little custom we have. She wrote me a letter the first day she met me, right as soon as she got home. She's written to me every day since. Even coming down on the train together she wrote me. You see, when I get a letter from her, it's sort of like a sort of visit, you see.
Hm -- mmm.
Judge -- we -- when two people get married, they usually go on a honeymoon.
I didn't. I don't approve of honeymoons -- waste of time!
Uh -- huh. Well, you know how women are, and Mrs. Mason and I --
What about Higgins against Higgins? You're the only one in the office who knows this case and it's on the calendar for next week.
If I could get a continuance --
Opposing counsel wouldn't consent.
But I talked to Mr. Hornblow this morning and he agreed to a continuance.
Well, all right -- take a week.
A week! Well, Judge, I'm afraid we wouldn't be able to make it ina week.
What?
We couldn't make it in a week!
Make what?
My wife and I had sort of planned a trip to Europe on the Normandie.
Oh, well -- take two weeks then.

An envelope is lying on top of a bouquet of dahlias in a large box. A hand comes in, takes the envelope and remove the note inside. CAMERA MOVES UP to CLOSE UP NOTE. It is written on the stationery of the law firm of Doolittle, Messerschmidt, Doolittle and Hutch. The note reads: Dear mother: Had to rush from the train to the office. Will be home fo tea this afternoon. Love, Johnny
P.S. Bringing with me a lovely girl I met in Boston.
CAMERA is on Mrs. Mason, Johnny's mother.
And after I got the cinder out of Jane's eye we talked for a little while and then we took a little walk around the Common.
Yes? CAMERA MOVES BACK to take in Johnny and Jane. Jane is sip her tea with exaggerated casualness.
And -- er -- We walked for quite some time. And then we went over to Thompson's Spa for a bite --
Yes?
(stymied)  And we had a bite.
Well! Rather an unconventional meeting, wasn't it? There seems nothing else to say.
(brightly) These cookies are delicious!
They're made with sour cream.
(blurts out suddenly I'm crazy about Jane! Mrs. Mason starts so violently she spills some tea.
(to Jane) John's so young and impulsive...
Oh, now Mother, wait a minute. This is different.
(to Jane) Are you visiting relatives here in New York, my dear?
Well, yes and no. We -- Not exactly.
I came over with Johnny.
(horrified) From Boston? Together? Last night?
Why, yes, Mother, we thought that as long as we were engaged --
Engaged!
Oh, I know how upset you must be, Mrs. Mason. You know so little about me -- and it all happened so suddenly --
Well I should think it was sudden! What did your family have to say about it?
I have no family.
Oh. (there is implied criticism in the syllable) Didn't John say something about your taking a course in journalism?
Yes, but I gave it up after I met Johnny.
Yes -- I'm sort of a post graduate course.

(her face brightens) Oh -- My dear, if you have a talent for writing -- (she becomes suddenly motherly) Take my advice and develop it while you're young. One needs all one's time and energy for a career.
Don't you think marriage is a career in itself?

Oh, indeed! Emphatically! That's why one mustn't rush into it pell-mell. Marriage is a business -- a very  serious business. A partnership in the strictest sense of the word. One must prepare for it. There are so many things to learn. Jane looks at Johnny.
Well, Jane'll learn all of those -- after we're married.
I hope and pray that that day will not come for many years!
Well, Mother -- What do you mean -- do you mean we shouldn't --
Emphatically not! There's no reason for Jane to develop into a little household drudge. Oh, I hope you understand I have nothing against Jane. In fact, I like her -- I like her very much.
Well, I'm glad you do, Mother, because... You remember a little while ago you asked Jane whether she'd come to New York to visit relatives? Jane waits breathlessly.
(continuing) Well, as a matter of fact, she has come to New York to visit relatives. She's visiting some right now -- you see -- He can't finish -- looks desperately at Jane.
We're married. Mrs. Mason stares at them uncomprehensively for an instan Her mouth opens and her hands go convulsively to her che
Ohhhh --
(pitifully) Now, Mother -- everybody gets married sooner or later --

(a cry of panic) Johnny, get the smelling salts! She rushes over and starts to chafe Mrs. Mason's wrists. Mrs. Mason is gasping for breath like a fish out of water Johnny hovers over her, agonized and scared.
What do they look like? Mother, where are the smelling salts? Mrs. Mason gestures weakly in the direction of the bathro Johnny rushes out. Jane vigorously chafes Mrs. Mason's wr
Mrs. Mason is stretched out on the divan. She looks as if she has just been brought home from the hospital. She spe in a weary, martyred voice.
Ohhhh... What's done is done. You'll have children of your own, I suppose. CAMERA DRAWS BACK to take in Johnny and Jane sitting in c which face the divan. They are haggard and dishevelled.
And you'll love them and devote your life to them, and then they'll grow up and leave you and you'll say to yourself, it's all right, that's the way it is, you've served your purpose.
Oh, Mother, don't excite yourself  any more.
Oh, I'm all right now. She starts to get up. Johnny and Jane help her to her fee She takes Jane's hand.

I wish you every possible happiness and joy. (her voice trembles) I think perhaps I'd better go to bed. I'm all right. I'm all right. (she starts to exit, then turns with a sudden grey thought) I'll find a place to live, of course.

Some place to live! Well, of course not Mother, you'll stay with us. (Mrs. Mason shakes her head) We're, well, we're going to finda new apartment. (again Mrs. Mason shakes her head) We've talked this over and Jane'll insist. Won't you, darling?
(not too convincingly) Why, we couldn't think of anything else.
(shakes her head desolately) Well, we'll see.
Mrs. Mason totters, turns abruptly and exits to her bed-r Johnny and Jane look after her.
Looking off after Mrs. Mason.
Well, you see, I told you it would be all right.
(as she goes into his arms) Oh, Johnny, maybe we shouldn't have gotten married. Maybe we shouldn't have gotten married at all.
Atmosphere of just before sailing. Through the Fade, the sound of a steamer whistle.
A steward passes through the crowd and comes down the gangplank calling:
All visitors ashore, please! All visitors ashore, please!

in the midst of a similar group bidding farewell to frien and relatives. All through the scene there is a constant movement of people in the background. Mrs. Mason tightly clutches a paper wrapped bag. A hoarse blast from the ste and Mrs. Mason goes rigid.
(to Jane) Don't let him eat too many strawberries.
I won't.
He gets rashes. And don't forget to  make him wear his raincoat in London.
I won't.
He had pneumonia once.
Oh, Mother, that was twelve years ago. I feel fine now.
(to Jane) And take good care of yourself, too. Mrs. Mason and Jane exchange an embarrassed embrace and a kiss on the cheek.
Goodbye, Mrs. Mason.

(choking) Take good care of him. She looks at Johnny an instant as if to fix his image in mind, then throws her arms around him. Her embrace is muc different than the one she gave Jane. She holds onto her as if she never expected to see him again. Johnny is touc and embarrassed.
Goodbye, Mother. Aw now, Mother -- it's only two weeks, you know.
(in a strangled voice) I know -- Goodbye. She finally lets him go.
Goodbye. She gives them what she thinks is a smile, but it's reall tense twisting of her lips. She starts to go, then she remembers something.
Oh. She hands the box she is carrying to Johnny.
What's this?
The heating pad. You forgot to pack it. She makes a feeble effort to wave to them and exits. John looks after her, perplexed and wistful.
With tears streaming down her cheeks, she moves past peop waving farewell to those on the boat. She turns once as i she means to wave too -- then turns and plods doggedly ah
Johnny and Jane come into the corridor glancing at doors. Johnny has the heating pad under his arm. They find their stateroom and go up to the door numbered 504.
Here it is.
Johnny and Jane enter and look around. It's the smallest first class cabin on the boat with a single bed in it. Th only other furniture is a tiny desk and a couple of chair
Jane tries to conceal her disappointment at the cell-like size of the room, but Johnny gets it.
Ah, what do you think of it?
(obvious hypocrisy Well, it's -- it's cozy.
It's the only one they had left. I think we can do better after the boat sails.
Oh, what for? I love it. It's so intimate. Jane spies a package on the luggage deposited by the desk
What's this?
It's heavily wrapped in tissue paper. Jane picks it up.
(embarrassed) Oh that! -- that's nothing -- He grabs it and keeps it out of her reach.
(eagerly) Is it something somebody gave you? Oh, I know it's for me. Let me see it!
(still embarrassed Oh, no -- no, it isn't.
(as though he were holding out on her) It is too. Let me see it!
But it's just something I forgot to pack.
Well, what are you being so mysterious about? Let me see it.
It's nothing... She takes the package and Johnny looks away, then watches her out of the corner of his eye, embarrassed.
I bet it's a going away present.
Jane's hands tearing off the wrapping.
Oh, Johnny, you shouldn't have done this. Her hand rips off the last piece of tissue revealing a pi of herself.
Jane looks at the picture, looks at Johnny, looks back at the picture, enormously pleased.
Oh, Johnny, you fool! (throwing her arms around his neck and kissing him)
(in a weak attempt to laugh it off) Well, gee whizz, I couldn't leave it in the office! He looks away, reacts to something off scene.
Jane --
(her head still on his shoulder) What?
You know, when I was in school I was taught that two things can't occupy the same place at the same time.
What? (she draws back, looks questioningly at Johnny, follows his gaze) Oh.
-- from Jane and Johnny's angle.
They cross over to the bed, stare at it.
Well, we'll get the steward to get us a bigger bed.
You couldn't get a bigger bed in here though.
Oh, I think it's big enough. She stretches out on one side of the bed and looks up at Johnny.
Wait till you try to turn around. Is it all right?
Sure it is. Johnny lies on the other side of the bed, puts his arm ar Jane and they sink back on the pillow.
Let's see. That's not so bad. Why there's oceans of room here. A look of blissful content steals over them.
They are luxuriantly stretched out.
(dreamily) Johnny, this is the first time in my life I've ever been away from America.
(almost purring) Me, too.
Isn't it just beautiful?
(the complete sophisticate) Yeh, yeh, I guess so -- (with a far-away look) Jane...
(meltingly) What, Johnny?
(reminiscently and tenderly) Do you remember that cinder I took out of your eye in Boston?
(positively overflowing with gooey love) I'll never forget it.

(self-recriminating) Do you know that I threw it away? I shouldn't have done that. I should have kept that cinder -- put it ina locket or something. If it hadn't been for that cinder, maybe we'd never have met...
(horrified at the very idea!) Don't say that, Johnny -- we had to meet.
(grudgingly admits) Yeh, yeh, I guess you're right. (but still clinging to his original fearsome idea) But still... if it hadn't been for that cinder --
Oh, Johnny -- isn't it just beautiful? A hoarse blast from the steamer whistle. She edges a bit closer to him and they turn to look at each other.
(with infinite tenderness) Bon voyage, darling.
(same manner) Bon voyage. They kiss.
Where is stateroom 504?
First room to your left, sir. There is a knock on the door. Johnny and Jane exchange a startled glance.
Come in.
Johnny and Jane get off the bed. The door opens and Carte enters. We get a feeling he has come on a mission which h finds exceedingly pleasant.
Well, hello, Carter. Nice of you to come down.
Judge Doolittle sent me.
He did? Jane comes into the scene. Johnny introduces her to Carte
(to Carter) Carter, this is Miss -- Mrs. -- This is my wife. Darling, this is Mr. Carter from the office.
How do you do?
Happy to know you. (to Johnny) It's a good thing I got here in time. You've got just ten minutes.
Ten minutes for what?
(hugely enjoys the moment) To get off the boat. Jane reacts to this. Johnny turns to her.
To get off the -- What're you talking about?
Higgins against Higgins.
(a note of doom in his voice) What about Higgins against Higgins?
Higgins against Higgins goes on the calendar for next week.
Oh, no, no. That's where you're mistaken. I got a continuance for a whole month.
You think you did.
I did! Why didn't you ask Hornblow about it? He gave me his word of honor.
(shrugs) Well, you know Hornblow.
(frantically) Johnny, they can't do this to you!
No, they can't do this to me!
What does Doolittle think he is -- a puppet?
What does he think I am -- a puppet or something?
Some kind of a pawn he can push around any way he likes?
Yes -- push all over the place?
(to Johnny) Is that what you want me to tell Doolittle?
(shouts) Yes! Flustered, Johnny addresses Carter apologetically.
Oh, Carter, wait a minute! Are you sure that Higgins case is going on next week?
Monday morning at nine o'clock.
Will you excuse us a minute? -- Jane -- Carter saunters out into the corridor, leaving the door o Johnny steers Jane to other side of room.
I'm glad you said that, Johnny.
Yeah -- yeah - Jane, look -- This Higgins versus Higgins is a pretty important case.
I don't care if it's the most important case in the world -- it isn't as important as our honeymoon, is it?
Oh, no -- of course not, darling. (Jane starts to wipe his mouth with her handkerchief) But what's the matter?
You've got lipstick all over your mouth.
(continuing) A lawyer is sort of like a doctor or  a soldier -- you -- you've got to disregard your own convenience.
Convenience! You don't call this a convenience! During this scene Carter can be seen pacing back and fort in the corridor.

No, no darling -- now listen, darling, believe me I'd tell Doolittle to jump in the lake -- even at the risk of losing my job, but if I win this case -- I have a chance to get into the firm. And -- And a firm like this -- He stops suddenly as he notes the expression on her face his jaw hardens.

(continues) But it's my honeymoon! And Doolittle knows it's my honeymoon! CAMERA PANS with him as he starts pacing back and forth. the background Carter paces in the corridor, passing the open door. Johnny looks up at the moment that Carter pass giving him a significant look.
(with inflection dimuendo) There are just some things a man just can't do. There are some things aman just can't do!
Crowd on dock waving farewells. Among them, Jane and John
Johnny and Jane are both glum -- Jane's eyes are wet -- a they look out toward the Normandie sailing away.
That Carter thought it was funny! He laughed! Oh, I hate that -- that liver-pill!
If they ever try pulling anything like this again, I...
And I hate that Judge Do-nothing. I -- I wish someone would step on that ear-thing of his.
Well, we still have the tickets here...
And I hope Higgins beats Higgins! (she breaks) Oh, Johnny -- He puts his arm around her and they stare bleakly out to sea.
Under it name plate containing a card with name: MR. AND MRS. JOHN H. MASON and under it the half of anoth card, with name:
A woman's gloved hand comes into Shot and presses button.
Annie, the cook, carrying a mixing spoon and flushed and grumpy from her labors in the kitchen, goes to the door a admits Mrs. Mason. Annie wears a black uniform covered by  large kitchen apron.
(holding forth a paper bag) The alligator pears, Annie. Annie grunts, snatches the paper package. Mrs. Mason has turned to take off her coat. She turns now hand it to Annie but finds she has gone.
(calling from bedroom) Johnny!
(as she passes bedroom) It's your mother-in-law.
Oh, hello, dear!

head_text.subj: AS MRS. MASON REMOVES HER HAT

text: Oh, would you mind fixing the place cards for me? I'm so late. They're right in there on the desk.
Certainly, dear. (she starts into dining room)
Jane's voice is continuing off scene as Mrs. Mason enters gives the table a critical once-over. It is set for six.

That girl took so long to fix my hair, I didn't get out of the place till half past six. It's still sopping wet. Mrs. Mason has picked up the place cards from the desk an crosses to table, sorting them.
(starts to fix place cards) You should have made an earlier appointment.
Jane, fixing up before mirror, reacts to this implied criticism.
(grimly) Yes, I should. (she rouges savagely) I thought I'd put Judge Doolittle on my right, of course.
Mrs. Mason is placing the cards.
Naturally.
And Mr. Carter -- I suppose I'll have to have him on my left.
You seem to think I've never done this before.
No, no dear. It's just that I never have.
Annie enters from kitchen and goes to sideboard. She open drawer to look for nut cracker.
You have the wine glasses on the wrong side, Annie.
(resentfully) The left side was the right side where I worked before.

(shakes her head) The right side was the water glasses, Annie. Annie exits to kitchen in a huff, giving the swinging doo push that causes it to swing violently. Mrs. Mason takes floral center-piece off the table and brings it over to t sideboard. Jane enters from bedroom, her hair in a net an wearing a house robe.
How do you think the table looks?
Isn't it a little crowded? Jane sees that the center-piece has been removed.
Oh, that girl will drive me crazy! She goes to the sideboard, takes the centerpiece and repl it on the table.
The things that pop up at the last minute! I had to borrow some finger bowls from the woman downstairs because we only had four. (she scans the place cards) Oh -- are you at Johnny's right?
I always have been.
I thought tonight I'd put Miss Doolittle there.
Oh well, of course, it's your party, my dear.
(re-arranges the place cards) Just this once. Do you mind?
Certainly not. (reminiscently) You know, I thought at one time that John and Eunice Doolittle --
(turns sharply) Yes?
But there was nothing in it... Buta lovely girl!
(abruptly) Would you be a dear and see if Annie has the appetizers fixed?
Of course, dear. (she exits to kitchen)
She picks up Eunice's place card and looks at it thoughtf
Annie is busy at the stove. She isn't accustomed to dinne for six and is in a violent temper.
I think you have too many on the plate, Annie. And shouldn't they be garnished? Where's the silver tray -- the one I gave them?
I don't know how many hands they  expect you to have in this place! There's just so much a body can do! I'm only human. Annie places tray before Mrs. Mason.
I'll fix the canapes for you, Annie, since you seem to have so much to do. (tastes salad dressing) A little too much vinegar in your salad dressing, Annie, I'm afraid.
I'm only human.
(looks toward stove) Oh, your potatoes aren't going to burn, are they? I'm afraid you put them on too early. Annie slams down mixing spoon and starts savagely out of kitchen.
Jane is continuing with her dressing. The grim face of An suddenly appears in the mirror.
I'm leavin'.
(turns, horrified) You're WHAT?
Right now. You can stand just so much. I'm only human.
But you can't do that! What's the matter?
I can't please everybody.
(understanding reference to mother- in-law and depressed -- then frantic) Oh... But, Annie -- my guests will be here any minute!

She takes the top off the soup kettle, tastes it, adds a little salt -- looks at the potatoes, adds a large hunk o butter -- opens oven, looks at roast, turns down gas jet. short, she completely edits Annie's dinner.
Well, I'll see you through dinner, but I'm leaving at nine o'clock sharp to catch the nine-thirty fairy boat to Staten Island -- an' nobody's goin' to stop me! (she exits)
(enters from bedroom, muttering under her breath) I'm only human. Mrs. Mason leaves kitchen as Annie enters it.
Watch the potatoes, Annie! Annie hits the door a smack and it swings violently behin her as she enters kitchen. Jane enters from living room a proceeds toward Mrs. Mason.
(gently tactful) Dear, Annie has so much to do -- the extra guests and everything -- Don't you think we'd better humor her  tonight -- sort of leave her alone...
(crucified) You asked me to see about the canapes --
I know -- but it's a great deal for one person to do. And too many of us telling her what to do only upsets her.
(at same time) Well -- I was only trying to help. A whistle from the living room interrupts them.
There's Johnny!
He steps up to greet his wife and his mother, holding something concealed under his coat.
I bet you forgot the wine! Triumphantly he produces the bottle from under his coat a hands it to Jane.

Old Granite Puss's favorite brand! (kisses Jane on lips and takes off his overcoat) I called up Doolittle's club and found out -- Pretty nice, huh? (throws overcoat on hall bench and kisses his mother on forehead -- reaches over and takes bottle from Jane -- looks at it) It's Burgundy and it sparkles! (hands it to his mother) Tell Annie to chill it, Mother. They'll be here any minute!  (to Jane) You'd better get dressed! (starts to take off coat and vest as he crosses to bedroom door, followed by Jane)
Johnny rushes in, flings his coat on the bed, and is ripp at his tie as he starts into the bathroom.
How's everything going?
Everything's lovely! An ultimatum from Annie and this one's final! She goes to the bed to pick up Johnny's coat -- his pants come flying out and drape themselves over her. The sound running water.
She's through tonight.
Johnny pops his head out -- quickly without even looking himself, giving himself about a seven-stroke electric sha INT.
(thunderstruck) Tonight!
It's all right. She'll see us through dinner.
(from bathroom) I don't see why you have so much trouble with servants. Down at the office we get all the help we want. Jane closes her eyes and grits her teeth.
I'd like to change places with you for just one day. The noise of the electric razor stops. Jane is taking Joh suit to closet. She hangs it up and comes out with differ suit.
Jane, for Pete's sake, what did you do with the witch hazel?
I didn't have it. Look on the third shelf back of the eye wash.
(grumbling) Always putting things behind things...
(putting Johnny's suit on the bed) That was a brilliant idea of yours, asking Eunice Doolittle at the last minute! She gets her dress from closet.
She and the judge are like corned beef and cabbage. They're always together. (he comes out in his underwear)
(takes off her robe) And that impossible twirp, Carter -- I suppose you had to ask him, too! Johnny gets a shirt from dresser and starts putting it on

Eunice had some sort of date with Carter. What could I do? (mumbles to himself) I not only do all that guy's work,  for him, but feed him as well. (reaches for his pants and starts getting into them -- one leg first) It's all going to be different when my name goes up on that door. Jane, getting into her dress, comes over to him. Johnny h one leg in his pants.
Oh, Johnny -- do you really think so?
It's practically up there now. What's for dinner tonight?
Roast beef.
Roast beef! Doolittle's delight.
You know, I tried to have Annie make Yorkshire pudding -- but she never heard of it.

Oh, that's all right. Between roast beef and Higgins against Higgins how can we lose? Yes, sir, that's going to be all right -- my name up there on the door. He starts to button his shirt. Jane assists him.
(as he buttons top button) Doolittle --
(buttons second button) Messerschmidt --
(buttons third button) Doolittle --
(buttons fourth button) Hutch --
(buttons last button) and Mason!
Oh, Johnny!
Well, didn't I win my motion for a new trial in Higgins against Higgins? I had a memo from Doolittle today.
Oh, you did. What did he say?
He said he couldn't have handled it better himself. And when he eats from your table tonight, he'll eat out of my hand. And will I tell Carter!
And will we hop the Normandie!
And will we go places!
And will we do things! (looks at Johnny) Darling, I don't like that tie. Wear the blue one.
(starts to take off tie) Holy Mackerel.
Johnny, does your name have to be last?
Well, for the time being anyway. You know what it means to a man to get into a firm like that?
(squirming with her dress) You know what it means to a firm to get aman like you in it? (turns her back to him) Here, hook me up. He comes behind her to hook her.
Pretty nice neck you've got there. (kisses her on the back of the neck)
As nice as Eunice Doolittle's?

What do I know about Eunice Doolittle's neck? I never even noticed she had one. (quickly changes the subject which is a slightly dangerous one -- looks at his wrist watch) Hey, do you know what time it is? Get dressed, will you?
I am dressed.
(gets into his coat) Come on then! (starts out the door) Old Granite Puss will be here any minute.
Good evening.  Johnny reacts, turns and starts toward his guests.
Judge Doolittle standing in a group including Mrs. Mason, Carter, and Eunice, the judge's daughter. Johnny and Jane come into the scene.
(fearfully) Good evening, Judge. I've got great news for you tonight, Judge. We're having roast beef. Roast beef for dinner, yeah.

Her face grim, a large serving platter in her arms. CAMER DRAWS BACK and we see she is serving Doolittle, squeezing against him so that he is in a very awkward position. An appalling silence hangs over the table. From the conditio of the various plates, we can see it is Annie's second ti around. Doolittle manages to spear a slice. He puts it on his plate and is about to reach for another when he finds that Annie has moved on to Jane. A little bewildered, Doolittle places the serving fork and spoon on the edge o the platter. He has to reach across Jane to do this.
With one prong of her fork she spears the very end of a s of asparagus and pops it into her mouth -- with an expres look at Carter, as if to say: whatever made me come here tonight?
He shrugs, sticks his tongue against his cheek, looks ceilingward and makes cabalistic marks on the tablecloth with the end of his knife.
She ignores her food and beats with her finger tips on th edge of the table. She seems to be nursing some secret grievance and stewing about it.

He saws away at a piece of meat that is making a bum out his knife. He gives up and leans forward with a gesture o his hand as if he is about to make a desperate effort to renew the conversation -- but the effort is abortive. He finds he has nothing to say.
She turns to Doolittle.
(rather loudly, in deference to Doolittle's deafness) Would you care for some more wine, Judge Doolittle?
Yes. Thank you.
(to Annie, at other end of table) Annie -- more wine for Judge Doolittle.
(loudly) There ain't any more. Doolittle decides to start on his salad. He can't find a salad fork. With a crucified expression, he uses his meat fork. Annie starts toward the kitchen.
(sharply) A salad fork for Judge Doolittle, Annie!
(as she exits into kitchen) I put one there. The swinging door closes behind her.

(desperately tries to  change the subject) Funniest thing happened to me the other day, Judge Doolittle -- I ran across the year book of my husband's class at college, and in the class prophecy he was picked out as the one most likely to succeed.
What's that?
(louder) The other day I ran across the year book of my husband's class at college, and in the class prophecy --
Oh, yes, yes -- yes.
Higgins against Higgins was quite an important case, wasn't it, Judge Doolittle?
We like to think all our cases are important. The little client of today may be the big client of tomorrow.
Oh, you're so right, Judge.
For instance, we got a client the other day...
Annie has been serving the dessert. She sets a plate of a liquid ice cream before the Judge. He stares at it.
Oh dear -- (at the breaking point,  but trying desperately to control herself) What happened to your ice cream, Annie? Annie continues serving the ice cream.
I told you to have the ice box fixed. She puts a piece of paper alongside Jane's plate. Jane lo at the note.
It reads: "I've got to leave. I want my pay. $12.00."
Annie is standing near Jane. Jane hands her the note and whispers to her.
(whispering to Annie) Annie, give this note to Mr. Mason. Annie departs with note.
She looks across the table and tries to mouth the import Annie's message to Johnny.
He mouths back inquiries. He can't make out what Jane is trying to convey.
Looking from Jane to Johnny, wondering what's going on.
Jane gives up and turns to Doolittle.
Johnny Is it true, Judge Doolittle, something new is going to happen in the firm this week? by this time has gotten the significance of the note. He rises and starts out. Johnny
(to Doolittle) Excuse me.
What?
Excuse me, please? exits. Doolittle continues.
Oh yes -- we're going to have a blood transfusion... I'm only speaking metaphorically of course. What I mean is we're getting some new blood into the firm -- appointing a junior partner.
Oh! She looks frantically toward the kitchen.
You couldn't stay and serve the coffee, could you Annie?
No!
Here's seven dollars -- and I'll send you --
(adamant -- in a loud voice) I want my twelve dollars now!
(whispering and trying to shush her) All right, Annie -- all right. I'll get it for you. I'll get it -- maybe. Turns to go out.
That's how to keep an old firm young. I've been doing this every five years and it's quite a job to pick the right man. Johnny comes out of the kitchen. Doolittle frowns at the interruption.
Johnny --
(as he passes the table) Excuse me -- (he proceeds to the living room)
(answering Doolittle) I shouldn't think so. Surely it's a question of merit --
He rummages through Jane's bureau drawer -- stockings and handkerchiefs falling out, etc... finds her purse, takes a small roll of bills, closes the purse, restores it to i place.
As a rule I always trust my own judgment, but when it comes to picking men --  Johnny enters from the living room.
Johnny --
Excuse me -- He exits again into the kitchen. Doolittle is more annoyed than ever at the continuous interruptions.
(continues) ...I think there's nothing like a woman's intuition.
Oh, you're so right, Judge.

Of course, Eunice doesn't know much about law -- but she's traveled all over the world and she does know people. Five years ago it was at her suggestion that I took Mr. Hutch into the firm. It worked out so well... Johnny enters from the kitchen and takes his place at the table.
I beg your pardon -- I'm very sorry...

(continues his speech) ...that this year I have again consulted my daughter. And now a new name moves up on the door of our offices. (Johnny and Jane listen eagerly) Beginning next Monday, the name of the firm will be -- Doolittle --
Waiting expectantly for Doolittle to announce the new fi member.
Messerschmidt -- Doolittle -- Hutch -- and Carter.
She reacts in keen disappointment. She looks across the t at Johnny.
Trying to rise to the occasion, he stands...

Well, Carter -- Congratulations! It's wonderful. I always knew you had it in you... I'd like to propose a toast to the new partner -- only -- we -- seem to have run out of -- wine. There isn't any more wine. His voice cracks on the last word and he sinks to his cha
She looks at Johnny trying to smile -- the tears running down her face.
Upon which is written:

CAMERA DRAWS BACK as the door opens and Jane comes out -- excited, starry-eyed, almost cross-eyed with the import o news she has just received from the doctor. CAMERA PANS w her and she goes to a desk at which is seated a nurse, bu engaged with filing cards.
(tremulously)  May I have some paper and an envelope, please?
Certainly. She hands Jane a sheet of office stationery and an envelo

Thank you. CAMERA PANS Jane over to a little writing desk. She sits down, reaches for the pen and draws a large heart in the center of the sheet. In her excitement she begins to hum "Columbia, The Gem of the Ocean" as she starts to write a note within the heart.
Would you like a stamp?
No thank you.
Humming and writing. She looks up.
Could I have a safety pin, please?
Surely. She comes into the Shot and puts a safety pin on the desk

Thank you. Nurse exits. Jane fixes the safety pin on the note she ha just written, folds the note, encloses it in the envelope and writes furiously on envelope. She seals the letter an rises. CAMERA PANS with her as she starts to exit. The nu amused, turns to watch her leave. As Jane disappears thro the door --

CAMERA PANNING with him as he paces before the jury box. meet a new and startlingly different Johnny. He may be a worm to Doolittle -- a schnook to Jane -- and Little Lord Fauntleroy to his mother, but here he is in his element - the flaming advocate, concluding his eloquent summation t the jury in a burst of forensic fireworks.

And I tell you, gentlemen of the jury, the defendant Higgins, with unbrotherly venom and motivated solely by a desire maliciously and hatefully to interfere with his brother's rights and privileges --
The foreman is consulting a time table.
-- deliberately and improperly diverted the waters of the stream --
Featuring schedule of trains to Long Island. The foreman' finger is running down a list of trains. Now the train af the four o'clock is circled.

(fervently) Well, gentlemen, I leave the determination of these matters in your hands, confident that your verdict will bring justice to my client, the plaintiff in this action. Johnny wipes his brow and subsides.
He comes to with a start from something very closely approximating a nap and shakes his head to clear his drow wits.
Gentlemen of the jury --
The foreman's face puckered with anxiety as he looks at t table.
You will now retire to arrive ata verdict. The jury starts to file out of the jury box.

Seated at counsel table making notes. A bailiff comes ove and whispers in his ear. Johnny's face lights up and he t and looks toward the other end of courtroom. He rises and waves joyously -- then starts eagerly out of Shot.
Last row of seats in courtroom. Jane is seated there. Joh comes into scene and she moves over one seat to make room for him. He drops into the seat alongside and puts his ar around her waist.
I came in just as you started your summation, Johnny -- it was wonderful!
You should have been here when I cross-examined Higgins.
Your Higgins?
No -- the other one.
(passing through scene) You skinned him alive.
I tore him apart! I really cut him up --
Johnny -- She hands him an envelope. He grins at her and looks at i
On Dr. Langham's stationery and marked:
Johnny opens the letter and reads it. Jane is watching Jo with bated breath. Johnny's eyes open wide as he reads th letter and begins to gather its import.

Instead of one heart-shaped enclosure, there are two join together by the safety pin. Within the large heart is wri "The party of the second part wishes to announce to the p of the first part that we're going to be in the market fo lot of these for the -- Here a curved arrow points to the safety pin. Within the small heart is written: Party of the third part."
Johnny looks up at Jane. He is speechless with surprise a joy. He tries to say something but his bobbing Adam's app prevents speech.
(suddenly shouting) Jane! He takes her into his arms. Three men come into the shot.
Congratulations, Mason!
Good work!
You did a swell job!
It reads: MANHATTAN MATERNITY HOSPITAL

Asleep in bed. He has taken a room next to Jane's in the hospital. A blinking Neon sign from outside window is fla in his face. CAMERA MOVES BACK as he moves restlessly and suddenly awakes with nightmarish movements. Stupefied wit sleep, he fumbles with clock on bedside table.
It indicates a few minutes to four o'clock.
Johnny leaps out of bed, still more asleep than awake, ta another look at the clock, then quickly comes to life. He blunders into his bathrobe and slippers, putting on the f as he exits room.

As Johnny, still half asleep, comes into the hall. CAMERA PANS with him to adjoining room. Johnny listens, hears no he knocks softly on door, gets no answer, hesitates and t softly opens the door. Looks into the room.
It is brightly lit. CAMERA MOVES UP to the bed. It is emp but not made up.
He takes in the significance of the empty bed and registe  accordingly.
Johnny streaks away from his wife's room and runs down th corridor. As he reaches end of corridor;
It opens and Johnny, wild-eyed, pops in. A nurse walks in the scene and bars his further progress.
Is it -- happening?
It's happening.
Why didn't they wake me? I want to be with her -- I've got a right to be with my wife, haven't I?

(a little impatiently) All right. Wait a minute. You can't go in there until you put this on. He waits, tremblingly -- looking toward the opposite door The nurse comes back with surgical gown and mask. She hel him with the garment and mask. He keeps looking toward th opposite door.
The door swings open for a moment as another nurse comes of the delivery room. A quick glimpse of the activity ins before the door swings shut.
Johnny enters, walks toward operating table.
Jane sees Johnny and is just barely able to smile, makes weak effort to say, "Hello."
His lips move under the mask with answering greeting.
-- as he prepares ether mask.

head_text.subj: MASK COMING OVER JANE'S FACE 127 CLOSE SHOT

text: He has picked up Jane's hand and we get the reaction of t ether on her from the manner in which her hand droops out his.
across Johnny's back as he steps away from table -- beyon can be seen doctor and anaesthetist's activity - but John body covers view of Jane.
He reacts to activity.

Nurses -- Doctor -- Assistants -- Busy expert hands handi such instruments as may be permissible to doctor, etc. Over these Shots -- low and indistinguishable -- come the various voices of Doctor, Nurses and other appropriate so There are, however, no sounds of pain as Jane is under ha ether.
Reacts to activity.
In the eyes is double printed the activity in the deliver room.
Johnny in foreground blocking out Jane's body. We get a glimpse of the doctor and nurse as obstetrician holds the newborn baby.
as he holds the baby up by the feet. The obstetrician is slapping the baby's feet. It emits a tiny squeak.
Come on -- you can do better than that. (slaps the baby's feet again)
watching -- his eyes almost popping out of his head. Into the Shot comes the querulous wail of the newborn babe.
Atta boy!
Activity around operating table. It starts to go out of f
He slips to the floor in a dead faint.
A hospital bill with itemized account of hospital expense made out to John H. Mason. Cashier's hand comes into Shot and stamps a paid rubber stamp form on bill.
Now he's all yours, Mr. Mason. CAMERA DRAWS BACK as we see Johnny standing in front of  cashier's cage. Cashier hands Johnny the bill.
(as he looks at bill) All mine.
Come in again some time.
Thank you -- I will. (he starts to go, then realizing the import of her remark, stops for a moment, embarrassed) I mean I -- yeah. (he exits precipitously
As the traffic sign goes to "Stop" for 5th Avenue traffic 5th Avenue bus, a carriage, a taxi and a truck pull up an stop. In f.g., is a mounted policeman directing traffic.

Light turns to "Go" for 5th Avenue. LONG SHOT - FIFTH AVENUE CORNER (as before) Traffic stands immovable -- cars behind start honking -- people on bus, coachman, truck driver, etc., still lookin down into taxi. Irate cop gallops over towards taxi.
Across roof of taxi as cop rides into scene.
(bawling at driver) Hey! What do you think you're doing holding up traffic? He suddenly looks down and his expression changes to a br  grin.
Oh... What is it, boy or girl?
Jane is holding the baby. Johnny grins proudly. Johnny's expression.
What do you think?
The cop smiles, understanding. The horns honking and blowing again. Cop turns and after the impatient honkers.
Hey, cut that out! wake that baby! going. Do you want to All right -- get Traffic starts to move.
Johnny curiously embarrassed; Jane proud. indifferent.
Johnny?
Uh huh --
(softly) Like him?
(sheepish grin -- trying very hard to conceal his memotion) Sort of.
Don't you think he's... he's just Jane indicates start furiously starts furiously The baby alone is  beautiful?
(dodging the question) He... he looks old, don't you think?
Old? What do you mean, old?
I mean... he looks as though he were six months old -- or a year -- at least.
Oh, Johnny, you're silly... but don't you think he's just beautiful?
(dodging) I hope he grows up to look like you.
How can he? He has all your features.
I don't see how you can tell that by looking at that face.
Who looks like no one on earth.
Just look at the way his eyes crinkle... Just the way yours do when you're happy.
He doesn't look happy. He looks kind of bored.

Well, you'd be bored too, if you'd been through what he has... But don't you think he's just beautiful? Johnny has put out his hand. The baby has gripped his fi INSERT: Baby's finger gripping Johnny's
Boy, what a grip!
(tenderly) But don't you think he's just beautiful!
OPEN on CLOSE SHOT BABY in portable canvas babies' bath s up in bathroom. Jane's hands are sponging the baby.

Well, fella, how do you like your first bath? CAMERA DRAWS BACK to reveal Jane, in house gown giving th baby its first bath at home. Johnny, in shirt sleeves, is sitting on the edge of the tub, fascinated. Mrs. Mason st alongside watching and coaching. The advent of the baby h materially changed the appearance of the bathroom. A clothesline is rigged across the room and on it hang thre diapers held by clothespins. A baby's scale sets on the closed seat of the toilet, or a clothes hamper or etc. Jane handles the baby very ginge
Be sure you soap his head thoroughly. It prevents cradle-cap.
(still pleasantly) Yes, Mother. I know.
(more baby talk to baby)  Ittie Johnny doesn't want nasty old cradle-cap, does oo?

Look at those shoulders! Can I do something Jane? (pleadingly) Please! He reaches for baby as Jane lifts him out of the water. T movement makes Jane almost let it slip through her hands she exclaims in fright:

(panicky) Now look what you've done! I almost dropped him! Do move over, Johnny -- please! Her back to CAMERA, she holds the baby in her arms as she pulls over the canvas top of the tub and lays the baby on it.
If you'd let me show you how --
(not quite so pleasantly) I know how. They showed me at the hospital. (she is now drying the baby, her back still to CAMERA)
You don't rub the baby dry. You just pat him.
(beginning to wear thin) I am patting him.
He looks red. Maybe the water was too hot.
(pleasantly) No, Mother. It was just right. I tested it.
(to baby in baby talk) Was its 'ittle water too hot for ittie Johnny?
(she turns to Johnny) Johnny, will you hand me his shirt? Johnny reaches for the wrong garment.
Not that one! This one. She gets the shirt, starts to put it on.
(admiringly) Look at the chest on him! (eagerly) Can't I help? Neither woman pays any attention to him.
Be careful of his little head, my dear.

(still pleasantly) I will, Mother. Johnny, you'd better go in the kitchen and warm his milk. PAN WITH JOHNNY as he starts out of the room. He almost collides with the clothesline and has to stoop in order t get by it; almost knocks over the scales as he exits.
(calling to Johnny Not too hot, John!
The baby is now all dressed for the night, and Jane has h safely cradled in her arms.
(fervently) Hallelujah! (with great sigh of relief) He's bathed!

Mrs. Mason stands over the crib. Jane is wearily stretche out in a chair near the crib, her arms and legs stretched fatigue, her eyes closed: the mother just back from the hospital. The baby is crying lustily. They look harassed.
A touch of colic.
(without opening her eyes -- wearily) No, Mother, he's just hungry.
(with maddening tolerance of her daughter-in-law's stupidity) I'm sorry, my dear, but it's colic... He's been crying for five minutes. Jane closes her eyes and controls herself with effort.
(sitting up a little, calling impatiently) Johnny! Where's that bottle! Johnny comes in from kitchen, triumphantly carrying the b bottle.
(goes toward the crib) Here, fella -- the feed bag!
The baby still squawling -- Johnny trying to put the bot into its hands.
Baby's hands fighting off bottle, as he continues to bawl
Jane comes into scene. She yanks the bottle from Johnny.

They don't eat with their hands, you dope! She rolls up her sleeve and tests the temperature of the milk by spilling a few drops on her forearm, looking at J in a superior manner and shaking her head. She lowers the bottle toward the crib.
As Jane forces the bottle into its mouth. His squawling c instantly and he sucks the nipple with vehement appreciat
Again Jane goes to chair and sinks down wearily. The door rings. Johnny exits to answer it. Jane looks at the conte baby, then speaks to Mrs. Mason:
(lies back in her chair, closes her eyes) You see Mother, he was hungry.
If he were fed on time he wouldn't cry.
(Her eyes still closed, her hands tighten on the arm of the chair) As soon as we're organized...
(interrupting)  Too bad he has to be fed on a bottle.
(sighs -- grimly) I haven't heard the baby complain yet.
John never saw a bottle till he was six months old.
Controlling herself, speaks as inaudibly as possible -- practically to herself:
(as she speaks she clenches her hands on the arms of the chair) I won't say anything. I won't say anything. I won't say anything...
What's that, my dear?
Johnny comes in -- carrying a flat, small package already half unwrapped.
What do you think? It's a present from old Granite Puss... He sits down beside Jane, starts unwrapping the package.
I'll bet it's a summons.
No -- it's a bank book.

Johnny's hands finishing opening package. It contains a b book showing that an account has been opened in the name John H. Mason, Jr, with an opening deposit of $10.00 -- a  accompanying it is Judge Doolittle's business card. Johnny's hand turns the card over. On it is handwritten: "A penny earned is a penny saved."
He's deposited Ten Dollars. (he hands Jane the open bank book.) Mrs. Mason glances over Jane's shoulder.
Say -- that's a lot of money for the little guy.
I hope it doesn't plunge Doolittle into bankruptcy.
After that hospital bill he's got more cash in the bank than I have.
(very superior) I think it's very considerate of Judge Doolittle to think about the baby's future.
I'm not worried about his future -- It's the present that bothers me... Where are we going to put him?
Why can't he stay in our room?
You know he kept you awake last night.
(with demure over- sweetness) You should have taken that into consideration, my dear, before you  rented this apartment.
(too tired to argue) I know. I should have.
If my own room weren't so small --
(sweetly, forgetting and forgiving what she's been through) Oh, I wouldn't think of it, dear.
Hilda, the current cook, stands listening.
We could keep him in our room days and in the living room nights.
That's too far from the bedroom.
Well, in the dining room, then.
It's too near the kitchen -- but I suppose we'll have to. Hilda shows that she doesn't relish the idea of the baby being near the kitchen. She coughs to attract attention.
Mrs. --
Yes, Hilda?
(Swedish accent) Could I please see you a minute? Jane comes into the Shot.
What is it, Hilda?
Your mother-in-law hired me when you was away -- but she didn't say why you was away --
(tight-lipped) You mean you don't approve of my having a baby?
That's your business. You can have as many babies as you like.
(grimly) Thank you. That's big of you.
But my business is cooking. You get somebody else to wash the diapers. She turns and starts to exit. Jane calls after her, almos tearfully:
You're -- (with a wail) you're fired! Hilda pays no attention to this parting sally but continu her march across the room. Hear Johnny's Voice as Jane turns back into room:
(talking to baby -- very cheerful, oblivious to all the agony) Don't you worry, Johnny -- FOLLOW JANE AS SHE GOES BACK INTO THE LIVING ROOM and sin again into chair, almost exhausted.
Speaks softly, almost to herself:
I wish I could go back to the hospital.
Johnny talking to the baby.

As soon as the lease is up we'll get a house in the country with a room all your own -- and a garden to ride your bicycle in, and -- (he stops suddenly, open-mouthed, and looks up at Jane and his mother) Look! Mother! Jane! Look -- the baby! He's smiling -- he's smiling at me! Mrs. Mason bends over the crib... Jane runs in to look.
smiling.
(straightens and shakes her head condescendingly) That's gas!
You'll see all the Old Faces Wednesday Evening, October 5
Make Your Reservations Now!! Over this comes the sound of a clock starting to strike twelve.

The hall is lighted only by a dim light from the living r The sound of the clock striking continues. The sound of a key turning in the lock, the door opens, and Johnny enter He is in dinner clothes, black overcoat, and scarf. He se unusually dejected. He softly closes the door behind him starts on tiptoes toward the bedroom, CAMERA TRUCKING WIT HIM. Attracted by the light from the living room, he stop in the doorway and looks in at:
(from his angle) Jane, in a warm bathrobe, is curled up asleep. On the floor by the divan is an open book, face u A lamp on a nearby table is the only light in the room.

He tiptoes into the room, taking off his hat as he crosse and sits down on the floor near the divan, looks at Jane moment, moody and licked. Then he notices the open book o the floor. He puts his elbows on his knees, cups his chin and stares at the open book.

It is a year book of Johnny's college, open at the page bearing Johnny's picture. Over Johnny's picture, the word "Class of 1928" and under Johnny's picture: "Most Likely to Succeed" JOHN HORACE MASON
Jane stirs and opens her eyes, sees Johnny.
(from Jane's angle) Unaware Jane has awakened, his expres still moody and despondent, staring at the book.
From her expression we know that now she understands John mood.
Smiling, Jane sits up, puts her arms around Johnny and ki him.
How was it, Johnny?
Oh, swell.
Who was there?
Oh, just the same old crowd, only ten years older.
Who spoke, Johnny?
Ed O'Malley made quite a speech -- all about how he bought that seat on the stock exchange. And then Joe Kendall -- just got back from opening up a London office --
Did you make a speech?
Yeah.
What did you say?
You know -- the things you have to say at a reunion. Nothing much.
(insists)  What did you say, Johnny?
Well, my speech was pretty short. What would I have to say? (bitterly -- Johnny sees book on the floor) The man most likely to succeed.
Well, I think you have and I bet your speech was swell. (they kiss) Did you tell them that funny story you told me yesterday?

No -- no, I didn't think of it. All I could think of was my achievements -- What I've accomplished and how far I've gone. I suppose I should have told them how I used your money -- all of it -- to buy the furniture for this apartment.
Now, that's silly. Your money -- my money -- what's the difference? It wasn't much anyway.
I should have told them how the baby has to sleep in the dining room --
Well, what of it? And it's only temporary -- till we get a new apartment --
(over Jane's dialogue) -- because I can't afford to get you a decent place to live --
Stop it! Don't say those things! Sometimes I get so mad at you I can't see straight.
Sometimes I get so mad at myself I can't see at all!
I know what happened -- the dinner disagreed with you. What did you have?
I don't know -- I didn't eat any of it.
Now I know what's wrong -- you're hungry! (she rises, grabs his arm and yanks him up) C'mon, honey, I'll get you something out of the ice box. (she starts to pull him from the living room)
Johnny and Jane enter. Jane proceeds to the ice box, open it and starts to pry into it, taking things out.
Now let's see. Here's some cheese you like. And a whole cold chicken staring us right in the face. Which?
Chicken. Jane takes the platter and puts it on the kitchen table.
The trouble with you is you let people step on you! You do all the work in that office... Coffee?
No. Milk. Jane takes milk from the ice box and sets it on the tabl
You've forgotten more about law than Carter'll ever know. How do you expect people to recognize your value if you don't recognize it yourself?... White or rye?
Rye. She goes to bread box -- rummages in it.
They couldn't get along without you for one minute -- and you know it! Everybody knows it! She gets bread knife and starts to butter bread.
(eats a leg of chicken) Everybody but Doolittle.
He knows it too! But he takes advantage of you. I told you when he promoted Carter over your head that you should have quit -- walk right out on him!
Now, Jane, how could I? What about --
I know -- your mother and I. I wish you'd forget about us.
If I lost my job --
But you wouldn't! They'd never let you go! You're far too valuable! If you left, Doolittle would crawl to you on his hands and knees and beg you to come back.
(wry laugh) On his hands and knees! You don't know Doolittle.
I know you! All you've got to do is speak up -- stand right up to Doolittle! Don't ask for your rights -- demand them! He reaches for her hand and looks at the simple wedding b on one finger.
Remember the day in Boston when I got you this ring -- I promised to get you a better one later?
I don't want a better one later.
You liked the platinum one with the diamonds.
That can wait.
And the mink coat can wait too, I suppose. Probably in about three hundred years I can afford to buy you one.
What are you -- a man or a mouse?
A mouse! Jane grabs the kitchen knife and waves it in front of Joh as she talks:

John Mason, you know what's the matter with you? You're too modest. You don't appreciate yourself... I do  want that platinum ring! And I want a fur coat -- not the mink -- but a fur coat! And I want a honeymoon on the Normandie! And I want an apartment that's big enough for your mother and the baby -- so the baby wouldn't have to sleep in the dining room! You can get them for me! You can get everything I want -- everything that's coming to me! But first you've got to get what's coming to you!
If I only knew how to go about it --
It's easy.
You think it's easy.
You just walk right into the office and you say --
Jane, you don't walk into Judge Doolittle's office. He sends for you.
Well, this time you walk in. You go right up to him and you say: "Judge Doolittle, there's something I've got to say to you right now."
You can't talk to him like that though.
Have you ever tried?
Now Jane, you don't understand. If I barged in there like that he'd -- he'd --
He'd say -- "What is it Mason? Sit down."
He never asked me to sit down in his life.
Well then stand up. But don't let him interrupt you. Speak your piece.
Yeah -- well now that -- speak your piece. It's easy to do here in the kitchen. You get downtown...
Well, downtown or uptown, what difference does it make? You're not asking a favor of him. You're demanding your rights. He'll listen. Make him listen.
All right -- okay -- all right -- what'll I say? Jane has been gathering up the foodstuffs. She shoves wha left of the chicken into the ice box, turns out the light and they start out of the kitchen.
You'll say --
Jane and Johnny enter and start through to entry hall.

(continuing) "Judge Doolittle, I've been working for you now for five years and I've given you everything that's in me -- every ounce." They stop at the crib, look down at the sleeping baby. Du the rest of the scene Jane changes the baby's diaper as t talk. Johnny is still chewing on the leg of chicken.
Well, all right -- what'll he say?
There's no doubt about it, Mason. I've never questioned your ability or your loyalty --
And I'll say --
Judge Doolittle -- what're you going to do about it?
I hate to think what he'll say!
He'll say: Mason, what do you expect me to do? And you'll say: The right thing, Judge Doolittle... I want more money and I want to be taken into the firm! And he'll say:
He'll say plenty!
No matter what he'll say -- you'll say: Jane has finished changing the baby. With a last fond loo she turns and starts into the bedroom, Johnny following.
Jane and Johnny enter. Jane still talking.

(speaking as if she were addressing Judge Doolittle in person) Judge Doolittle, I either get a raise and a junior partnership or else -- (Johnny waits breathlessly) Or else you can accept my resignation, effective immediately.
(with grim determination) Effective immediately. That's all right, Jane. That's a good idea. I'm going through with it -- one of these days.
One of these days is tomorrow.
(aghast) Tomorrow?
Tomorrow morning at ten o'clock.
Well -- if you think I should!
(vehement) There's no time like the present.
(gulps) Let's start at the beginning, Jane. I'll walk into his office and I'll say --
Judge Doolittle, there's something I've got to say to you right now!
(waving his shoe at his reflection in the mirror) Judge Doolittle, there's something I've got to say to you right now!
Either I get a raise and a junior partnership --
Either I get a raise and a junior  partnership --
Or you can accept my resignation --
Or you can accept my resignation -- (without Jane's cue) Effective immediately.
(tenderly and proud) Effective immediately!
Not bad.

An alarm clock on the night table next to Johnny's bed. I registers shortly before three a.m. CAMERA PANS over to J She is asleep. She wakes suddenly and looks over toward Johnny's pillow, sees that it's empty, then attracted by sound, looks toward window.
Silhouetted in the moonlight is a figure in pajamas. It i Johnny, gesticulating fiercely, rehearsing in a sibilant whisper.
I've been working in this office for the last five years and there's something I want to tell you right now -- Either I get a raise anda junior partnership -- Or else...
(repeats, tenderly) Or else -- (she smiles and closes her eyes)

OPEN on CLOSE SHOT pieces of scratch paper littering John glass-topped desk, covered with scribbled designs and вЂњdoodlings." A hand comes into Shot and draws four larg exclamation points on one of the pieces of paper. (Under the glass top are many snapshots of Jane and the b in various poses.) CAMERA DRAWS BACK, and we reveal that it is Johnny who ha been sitting at his desk scribbling. He throws his pencil down and rises; starts to pace up and down the room nervo He mumbles to himself, rehearsing the speech he is going make to Judge Doolittle:
(pacing) +..a raise and a junior partnership -- or else... The fusty old bookkeeper pokes his head in the door and J looks up, embarrassed.
(motioning) Judge Doolittle is in.
Okay! The bookkeeper exits. Johnny starts on another quick mumb rehearsal, pacing again.
(mumbling, then) -- Or else you can accept my resignation -- effective immediately.
(appearing in doorway) What is it, a jury case? Johnny whirls, guiltily and embarrassed.
Now, never mind. I'm thinking.
(holds out papers to Johnny) Here are the papers in City against Consolidated. Johnny takes the papers without answering.
I want you to drop over to Consolidated and see their accountants.
Okay. Carter goes down the corridor, just missing a collision w the office boy who pops his head in at Johnny's door.
(to Johnny) Pssst! (imitates Doolittle by flipping back his coat and motions back toward Doolittle's office with his thumb) He just got in.

Okay -- okay. As he pops out again, Johnny looks haggard and gulps. He stands motionless a moment, then in frantic hurry starts straighten his tie. He lays the papers on his desk, walks quickly to the door, and puts his hand on the knob.

Johnny stands there, gets a grip on himself and knocks timidly. Of course there is no response. Doolittle couldn possibly have heard the knock. He knocks again, just as softly, and hearing no answer, turns and is about to go b to his office when Doolittle's voice comes through the do
(bellows) Come in!
Doolittle is frowning over some papers in his hand. Johnn stalks into the Shot, blurts out his rehearsed speech.
Judge Doolittle, there's something I've got to say to you right now -- Doolittle is intent on the Income Tax statement. Johnny c gently.
Judge Doolittle -- (Doolittle looks up) I've been working in this office --

Oh, it's you! (grimly) You're just the one I wanted to see. (indicates a chair by his side) Sit down. Johnny, surprised at the unexpected invitation, sits on t edge of the chair and waits. Doolittle leans back in his swivel chair, adjusts his glasses and rocks slowly, fixin basilisk gaze on Johnny.
Mason --
Yes, sir?
You've been doing mighty good work lately. Johnny smiles. The old man is actually going to make it e for him!
Johnny Johnny Johnny Thank you, Judge.
You've been capable, dependable and loyal -- right from the start! is so tickled he actually crosses his legs.
(his chest comes out a little) That's mighty nice of you, Judge!
But, Mason -- these are extraordinary times -- For all of us! uncrosses his legs.
Some of our biggest clients are affected. They all complain they're practically working for the Government. is rigid in his chair again.

Most of them claim it'll be all they can do to stay in business till the next election. So they're cutting expenses right and left -- and we're the first to feel it. Naturally we have to do something about it.
(with sinking heart) Naturally.
(flips open his coat) What?
(repeats, louder) Naturally!

I don't want to cut down the personnel  of my staff if I can possibly help it. -- Wouldn't be constructive. So the only way out -- as I can see it -- is to tighten our belts. I'm asking everyone to take a twenty-five percent cut. I'm starting by taking a substantial cut in my own personal drawing account. It's a sacrifice, but it hits all of us. These are days of sacrifice!
I know, Judge, but I --
These are times when we all have to put our shoulders to the wheel -- if we're to survive!
Yes, sir, our shoulders to the wheel -- Only I --
I'm glad you understand, Mason -- I appreciate your cooperation.
(miserably) Thank you, sir. Doolittle's phone rings.
(reaches for phone) Hello -- (glances up at Johnny) Excuse me, Mason. Johnny rises and starts out. We hear Doolittle continuing into telephone:
Hello, Commissioner. -- You know that little piece of property on Park Avenue? Well -- if the price is right --
Johnny comes out, his face a mask of doom as he starts ba to his office.

Johnny enters. We can see at once that our hero has sough comfort and slight consolation in the grape. He has had a few drinks and his courage has obviously been falsely bolstered by the liquor. He is slightly tight but in no s drunk. He glares defiantly ahead, then slams the door violently shut.
The slamming of the door awakes Mrs. Mason and she sits quickly up as if she were goosed.

Making as much noise as possible, Johnny goes into the li room, turns on the switch which lights the central lighti fixture, and goes from lamp to lamp turning them all on. Then he stomps into the dining room, still making as much noise as possible, turns on all the dining room lights, a stomps on out to the kitchen.
The baby wakes up and lets out a yelp.
Jane hears the baby cry and gets out of bed, exiting towa dining room.
Johnny opens the ice box, brings out a bottle of milk and starts pouring it into a glass. The bottle falls to the f with a crash. The door opens a crack and Lily sticks her head out.
Did you want something, Mister Mason?
No thank you, Lily. Lily's head disappears.

Jane quiets the baby. In a minute Johnny comes out of the kitchen, not bothering to turn out the lights after him. hat and coat are still on. His overcoat swings open and w see his suit and coat splattered with milk. He looks at J defiantly.
(belligerent) Well?
(still bending over the crib -- very casually) Good morning, Johnny.
(explosively) Good morning. (he exits toward bedroom, Jane following)
How do you feel?
I feel fine! (he flings his hat across the room) They go into the bedroom.
As they enter, Johnny takes off both his overcoat and his suit coat at the same time and lets them slip to the floo Jane goes to the mirror, casually fixes her hair.
What time is it? Johnny flings down his vest.
(in a mounting voice -- each hour louder) Three o'clock! Four o'clock! Five o'clock! High noon! (takes off his tie and throws it down)
(very quietly against his obviously synthetic rage) It's just two, isn't it?
If you know the time why do you ask me? What difference does it make what time it is? (starts to take off his shirt) I feel fine. He flings his shirt to the floor and exits to bathroom.
Johnny enters -- bumps into the line of diapers, angrily rips down the cord and the diapers fall to the floor.

Now the sound of running water from the bathroom. Jane lo toward the bathroom with lowered lids, shakes her head, thinking what to do. Johnny's pants come flying into the room. Jane thinks a moment, then exits toward entry hall.
Jane goes to light switch, puts out central chandelier li then goes from lamp to lamp, putting out all the lights J lit.
Her light is now on. She is sitting up in bed listening w an expression of rage on her face. Finally she turns the light out viciously and sinks back into bed to sleep.
Now in pajamas at sink. He is filling a glass with mouth wash. He starts to gargle -- he gargles very loudly.

Jane enters and starts to pick up Johnny's clothes. Johnn loud gargling comes from the bathroom. Jane neatly folds Johnny's clothes and starts to hang them up in clothes cl as Johnny enters and goes directly to bed, pulling blanke over him. We do not see Johnny's feet in this scene.
She carefully hangs up Johnny's clothes.
Feel better now?
Johnny curled up under blankets.
I feel fine!
Are you comfortable?
Plenty comfortable.
Are you sure you're comfortable?
She finishes hanging up Johnny's things.
Certainly I'm sure I'm comfortable! Jane looks down at the figure curled up under the blanket
(softly -- politely) Don't you think you'd be more comfortable if you took off your shoes?

Johnny sits upright -- flings the blankets off and stares his feet. He has forgotten to take off his shoes. He swin over and sits on the edge of the bed, bending down to tak off his shoes. His fumbling fingers have trouble with the shoe laces. Jane enters.
Can I help you? (she gets down on her knees)
I don't need any help! I feel fine! But he lets her take off his shoes anyway. He suddenly explodes into an indignant tirade against nothing in particular.

(waving his arms as Jane takes off his shoes) What time is it? Am I comfortable? How do I feel? You'd think I committed some sort of crime! You'd think I was on the witness stand! A man comes home looking for a little peace and quiet, and what happens? Blah-blah- blah! Why didn't I call you back? Why didn't I come home for supper? A million questions just because a man --

(without looking up,  speaks matter-of- factly) I ran into Judge Doolittle this afternoon -- after you saw him. There is a silence. She looks up to find Johnny staring a her. His face is such a mask of misery she can hardly sta it. She rises from her kneeling position, sits on the edg of the bed alongside of him, takes him in her arms and hu him tightly.
(almost a sob) Oh, Johnny -- you fool! What does it matter if you get a raise or a partnership -- or anything!
(muffled against her bosom) Oh, Jane -- I let you down! I'll always let you down! I'm no good!

(a wall of anguish) Johnny, don't say that! It was my fault for interfering. I made you do it and I'm terribly sorry... I'll never do it again... never. We don't need anything -- we've got each other and the baby -- our beautiful baby -- You're all I have and all I want -- (sobbing) -- and please -- if you feel bad I'll die!
Johnny's head is lowered. He doesn't answer. A little pau

Johnny, Johnny, look at me and tell me you don't feel bad! Another second's pause, then Johnny slowly lifts his head with a grimace he thinks is a smile. His eyes are wet. Ja sees his expression and starts to cry. He is completely ashamed, puts his arms around her, and attempts to comfor her.
Jane -- I don't feel bad. They hold on to each other desperately, both of them cryi all the more.
(tears rolling down his cheeks) Jane -- I don't feel bad. (as Jane sobs convulsively) I feel fine -- honest I do. They cling to each other desperately. Jane kisses his tea away.
(laughing through her sobs) Johnny, the next time you go out and get tight... you'd better take me... along with you... or I'll... I'll get a divorce...
(abortive attempt at laughter) You'd better get a good lawyer.
(hysterical laughter) I've got a good lawyer.
Johnny gives a sedate little burp, as we

head_text.subj: SHEETS OF PAPER DRIFTING DOWN THE SCREEN

text: There are bills of all sorts -- installment furniture, ma milk, telephone bill with discontinue threat -- the bills are stamped: "Over-due" -- "Please pay up" -- "Please rem etc. Included, perhaps is a reminder of a note due from t Morris Plan Bank. The falling bills change to falling lea
Over this comes the high-pitched voice of Lily.
Keep coming -- Come on, keep coming -- Come on now. CAMERA DRAWS BACK, as we see that the baby is crawling af a little toy cat. Lily (Louise Beavers) on her hands and knees calling to the baby.
If you want something you gotta go get it.

shot type: TAKING IN PATH ALONG THE GRASS
