text: Jane comes into the Shot and pauses as she hears Lily's v She seems weary and downhearted, but her face lights up a she looks off scene. She carries a folded newspaper in he hand.
That's it -- come on now! Come on! Jane starts toward them.
The baby reaches the cat and grabs it as Jane comes into Shot. Lily laughs, high-pitched, as she sees Jane, and clambers to her feet.
(excitedly) Mis' Mason -- you should have seen him travel! Jane sinks wearily onto the park bench, dropping her news beside her.
Lily's smile changes to a look of concern as she looks at Jane.
Is you tired?
I've been all over town. My head's splitting. Lily comes up behind her.

Lean back, and let Lily rub the back of your neck. Jane's head goes back against the capacious bosom of Lily standing behind the bench. Lily starts to rub Jane's neck with strong capable fingers. With a sigh of content Jane closes her eyes.
Been visitin' 'round, Mis' Mason?
Uh-huh.
(casually) Does Mr. Mason knows you's lookin' for a job?
(opens her eyes) Who says I'm looking for a job? She looks back at Lily, sees that Lily is looking at some and follows her gaze.
Opened to the "Situations Wanted" ads.
Jane realizes how Lily knows.
Lily, it isn't nice to go prying into other people's business.
"Scuse me, Mis' Mason.
(closes her eyes again -- after a pause) Lily, you must be the fifteenth woman I've had working for me since I've been married, and you're too good to be true. You're worth your weight in gold.
(grins) That's a lot of gold.
(almost breaking You're the best woman I've ever had in the house -- just simply perfect -- and that's why it just breaks my heart to have to tell you --
Never you mind, honey. I knows I'ma luxury. A moment's silence while Lily rubs Jane's neck.
I'd never let you go -- never -- only I --
Shucks, honey, you ain't gettin' rid of me -- you're just gittin' me off the budget. Is the head better?
Much better... (with a wail) I'll make such a mess of things without you.

No you won't -- you'll step right in and do the job. And it's a pretty good job, too -- a whole lot better'n you can get on the outside. Takin' care of a nice young man an' a sweet  lil' baby an' a old lady that's jes' a little persnickety -- that's 'cause she's gittin' along an' don't have nothin' to do.
I wish it were as simple as that.
(reaches down and takes Jane's hand) Lily's a lot older than you are, honey. She's done a lot o' livin' an' she's learned one thing: Never let the seeds stop you from enjoyin' de watermelon!
(cather wistfully and with slight bitterness) That's all right if you've got watermelon.
(reproachfully) Don't say dat, Mis' Mason. You got your watermelon. But you're chokin' up on all dem li'l seeds. All I say is "Spit 'em out! Spit 'em out, before they spoils your taste for the melon!
(thoughtfully) Spit 'em out...
The words: "HAPPY NEW YEAR" in blinking neon lights.

(New Year's Eve) The room presents a sorry contrast to the gay revelry go on outside. There is a distinct aura of let-down and depression. Sitting in an easy chair is Mrs. Mason a shaw over her shoulder, sniffing at a tube of benzedrine and q miserable from a cold. Johnny, in evening clothes, is spr on a window seat playing with the baby's toy cat, winding up and listening morosely to the music-box tune. The only sound, except for what drifts in from the celebration in street, is the tune from the music-box. Jane's wrap and Johnny's overcoat are draped over a chair.
She opens her mouth, fights it a moment, then sneezes violently.
(morosely) Bless you. Another sneeze from Mrs. Mason.
(mournfully) Bless you. (she turns to Johnny) Are you sure Carter has our telephone number?
If he hasn't he certainly has a telephone book.
Then why do you suppose he hasn't at least called up?
(sniffing) Perhaps he forgot all about it.
Mother, a man doesn't invite you to a New Year's Eve party and then just forget about it.
Maybe we ought to go join him at the party.
(a little exasperated) Jane, I told you I don't know where the party is. He said he'd call for us here in his car at nine o'clock sharp.
Well, it's almost eleven now.
Isn't the party also to announce his engagement to Eunice Doolittle?
Something like that.
Well, perhaps he thought it might be a little awkward to have you and Jane at his engagement party.
(sharply) Now, Mother! How could it be awkward?
Awkward or not awkward -- are we going to sit here all night waiting for him? Let's call him up! Johnny drops the cat to the floor, rises and exits to out hall.
(almost as if she's talking to herself) All the same it might be awkward.
Why should it be awkward? Before Mrs. Mason has a chance to go into detail, there i the sound of a little sneeze from the direction of the di room. Jane quickly starts in that direction.
Johnny viciously dialing his number. Jane passing in b.g. way to dining room. INT.
Jane comes into Shot just as the baby sneezes again.
-- sneezing. He has a runny nose.

She his She her kisses the baby on the cheek, then puts her hand over forehead, and straightens up, CAMERA PANNING WITH HER. looks off toward Mrs. Mason in the next room, presses lips together and shakes her head disgustedly. Johnny's voice drifts in from off scene as he calls Carter's house
First Johnny enters from the hall, then Jane enters from dining room.
They say at Carter's house he left two hours ago. We'd better forget it.
The baby definitely has the sniffles.
(talking through her head cold) All babies have sniffles this time of the year.
He caught his cold from you, Mother.
That's simply ridiculous! Matter of fact, I caught my cold from the baby. He's had sniffles all day. When I took his temperature --
That's when he caught your cold.
He certainly didn't! He had no temperature.
(trying to pour oil on the troubled waters) It's all right, Johnny -- it's just the sniffles!
I suppose I ought to stay in my room all day!
(placatingly) Now, Mother, that's silly. You don't have to do anything of the kind!
Heaven knows I try to earn my room and board by being as helpful as I can!
Oh, Mother, please -- it's New Year's Eve!

It's just like any other day as far as I'm concerned. (with rising self- pity) You're both perfectly willing to leave me all alone to wait for the New Year, when perhaps it's the last New Year I'll ever see.
(holding onto his temper) Mother -- why do you keep saying things like that? There is a ring at the doorbell.
It's Carter! Johnny exits to outer hall.
Johnny comes up to the door with Jane behind him. He open the door. Lily, all togged up in New Year's Eve finery an with traces of confetti on her clothes, comes in with a l basket in her hand.
(grinning hugely) Evenin', Mister Mason!
Hello, Lily.
Happy New Year, Lily.
Happy New Year, Mis' Mason. I want to leave this with you. Lily hands Jane the basket. Jane lifts the paper and she Johnny look into the basket.
(looks up -- gratefully) Lily, you sweet old thing!
It's nothin' at all. I had the day off so I cooked up the chicken and the place where I work gimme de wine.
She is looking out disapprovingly toward the hall.
Happy New Year to you all!
Happy New Year to you!  (he starts back into the living room)
Happy New Year, Lily. Have a good time.
All right -- goodbye. Lily exits. Jane closes door and starts back toward livin room.
-- as Johnny enters.
(lugubriously) That solves everything -- now we won't have to go out! We'll stay right here and celebrate. Jane now comes in carrying the basket.

(sets the basket on the arm of Mrs. Mason's chair) We'll open up the wine now and at midnight we'll have a grand feast on Lily's chicken! (pleadingly) Come on -- it's New Year's Eve -- let's have fun!

You know I get indigestion if I eat just before I go to bed. (sighs, looks over at chicken) Maybe there'll be some left over for me tomorrow. I never did approve of Lily -- she's much too forward -- but I do miss her cooking!
(hurt) That doesn't say much for mine.
Oh, you'll learn, my dear. It takes time of course.
She grits her teeth and mutters.
I won't say anything. (she reaches for a book, opens it in the middle)
Times are different now. When I was married, every well brought up girl knew something about cooking. Jane suddenly explodes, slams down the book in her hand.
(turning) Why, Jane -- what is it?
I can't cook!... I can't keep house!... I don't know how to bring up a baby!...
Now Jane, please -- (he starts toward the two women)
I'm sure I don't know what you're talking about!
(tense with rage) Oh yes you do! You've resented me from the first moment you saw me! You resented me because you wanted Johnny to marry Eunice Doolittle!
(injured) My dear, I never said anything like that!
You've hinted it often enough!
(indignant) I've done nothing of the sort! But they were engaged.
Mother, I never was engaged to Eunice Doolittle.
Not what you'd call engaged, perhaps --
And even if I were, you shouldn't keep mentioning it to Jane all the time.
I can't understand why she's so touchy about it.
Touchy! That's why you hate me!
(agonized) Jane -- will you please --
(tosses her head) No -- let her go on. She can say anything she likes -- I know my place here. I'm only a guest -- an unwelcome guest.
(tortured) For crying out loud! What's the matter with you two?
Mrs. sob, her. (shouts) Nothing's the matter with me!
(violently) It's her house!
(placatingly) Please, Mother --
It's not my house!
Now, Jane -- please --
I do the best I can to help!
Now, listen.
I'm the stranger around here! Everything I say is wrong! Everything I do is wrong!
Jane -- will you --
Just because I happened to mention that John and Eunice Doolittle --
(thunderous1ly) Now stop it! BOTH of you! Mason gives him a startled look, utters an anguished and exits rapidly, slamming the door violently behind
(turning miserably to Jane) There! You see what you made me say  to Mother!
(hotly) You said it to me too! Don't I count?
(at his wits end) Of course you count, darling -- only Mother's an old lady -- she won't be with us for very long. Why can't you get along with her?

(hysterical) Why can't she get along with me? Because she hates me! You don't know how it is -- you're at the office all day. Between taking care of the baby and the house and cooking and listening to her criticize everything I do -- I can't stand it any more! CAMERA PANS with her to bedroom door.
You can only spit out so many seeds! She exits into her bedroom, with a terrific slam of the d

He stands a moment, defeated and miserable -- then the fl of revolt registers in his face. He looks down at the flo and sees the baby's white cat where he had previously dro it. He kicks the cat viciously across the room. CAMERA PA with him to the chair where his hat and overcoat are. He picks them up, goes to the front door and slams out. CAMERA HOLDS a minute on the empty room, then:
Jane comes out, looks around for Johnny, CAMERA PANNING w her, then calls out in alarm:

Johnny! Johnny! She looks toward the chair in hall where her wrap and Jo overcoat had been. Jane's wrap is there but Johnny's over is gone. She quickly grabs her wrap and flies to the oute door, calling as she opens it and runs out:
Shooting down over stairway and over Jane's head. Down a flight we see Johnny, going down. Jane enters quickly, carrying wrap.
(screaming) Johnny! Johnny stops, turns and looks up.
(surly) What?
-- as Jane comes galloping down, talking as she does.
Where are you going? Johnny turns away as she catches up with him and stops on step above him.
Oh, I don't know. Anywhere to get away from that wrangling.
Wait a minute! (she runs down the steps and joins him) Don't you want me to go with you?
Well -- can't you understand a man wants to be alone once in a while?
I'm sorry, Johnny -- really I am.
(coldly) You don't have to apologize.
(hurt at his failure to respond, but really trying to help) Would you rather I didn't come with you? He doesn't answer. Jane continues pleasantly -- with a sa little smile.
All right, Johnny. I don't mind. You go along and have a good time. (she turns and goes up a step)
(less than half-hearted) Oh -- Come on along if you want to.
(she turns) You're sure you don't mind?
(without enthusiasm) Certainly I don't mind... Jane advances and takes his arm.
(like a little girl) We'll have a wonderful time -- you just wait and see...
The place is crowded. Gaiety reigns. The tiny dance floor is packed with hilarious couples.

There is an open bottle of wine on the table and before e a glass of wine. Before each of them also a plate contain a sandwich which has not been touched. Jane and Johnny ar not looking at each other, but are pretending to be inter in the scene about them. Johnny finally meets Jane's eyes.
Oh, Johnny, what's happened to us?
I don't know. Maybe I pulled a dirty trick on you when I took that cinder out of your eye up in Boston.
(with her heart in her throat) What do you mean?
I mean -- maybe the whole thing's been a mistake.
(stunned) What -- whole -- thing?
Our marriage.
(a quiet little cry of pain) Oh, Johnny.

(words pouring out of him now) I've gotten into debt -- I've gotten nowhere at the office and I've made a household drudge out of you, just as Mother said. Jane, it hasn't worked out -- it just hasn't worked out!
(pleading) But we've never had any real trouble. Maybe a few silly little things -- things that everybody has to meet when they get married.
Maybe we shouldn't have had the baby --
(this is a real kayo for her) Oh, Johnny -- you can't be sorry about the baby?

I'm crazy about him!... And about you too! I'd die for either of you. Jane, everybody that passes this table stops and looks at you. It's because you're young and so beautiful -- your whole life ahead of you --
(pleading) Ahead of us --

No -- not when you're dragged down by a guy who just can't make the grade. No, I'm not going to hold you to that kind of a contract. Jane leans back in her chair. She tries desperately to se matter-of-fact.

Well -- you ought to know all about contracts. (she shrugs and fights to keep her voice steady) Well, anyway, I suppose this is what you'd call starting the New Year right! Johnny is too miserable to say anything. Jane tries to ma her smile breezy and gay. She reaches for her glass of wi
At least we've finally got something we can celebrate. (she lifts her glass and her voice breaks) Well -- Happy New Year --

Happy New Year. He clicks glasses with her. Jane sips the wine and then b her head forward to hide her face from him for an instant He looks helplessly across the table at her and is about say something when she lifts her head. Her eyes are wet b she flashes him a dazzling smile.
Want to dance, darling? They rise and start toward the dance floor.
Jane and Johnny threading their way through the crowd tow dance floor.
They dance silently. A thunderous roll of drums comes int the Shot and all the dancers stop to turn toward the musicians.
The trap drummer plays a rolling of drums to usher in the New Year.

A crescendo of sounds -- whistles and other noise-making devices from the outside blend with the increasing shouts yells of HAPPY NEW YEAR within the cafe. The lights go out -- a whirling crystal ball from the cei of the cafe starts to turn -- various colored flash-light play against it and cross each other, creating weird ligh effects. From above a bunch of colored balloons tumble do Everybody in the near dark starts exchanging New Year's kisses.

They look off at all the other revelers exchanging kisses Johnny and Jane seem to be the only ones who aren't kissi They look at each other embarrassed, and Jane, as always, takes the initiative, looks into his eyes and then kisses him tenderly. Johnny starts to put his arms around her, b doesn't. The orchestra off scene strikes up "Auld Lang Sy The people sing. Johnny and Jane, holding hands, start to sing with frantic efforts at a gaiety that they try to wr from their leaden hearts. After the first four lines, Jane can no longer control he emotions, and she turns and starts away to keep from burs into tears. The singing continues.
I think I'll go phone the house and wish the baby a Happy New Year. Johnny takes a step to follow her.
Jane -- I'll -- But Jane has disappeared in the crowd.

(her face in Camera) "Auld Lang Syne" still continuing. Jane fights her way quickly through the crowd, tears stre from her eyes. A hundred balloons come from the ceiling - bibulous gents stretch arms out to stop her, but she proc fighting her way up toward a telephone booth. People call to her as she presses through, but Jane pays attention. One woman, seeing the tears in Jane's eyes, ca
Crying Jag! A happy drunk brushes past her:
Happy New Year, Blondie!  A man calls from a table as she passes:
Hey Sister -- Wait a minute ---
Hurry back, Honey! One of the balloons floats in front of Jane's face. A man hand with a cigar comes in, and pops the balloon. Serpentine and long paper whistles unfold in front of her face.

Johnny edges his way past people and sits down at the tab leaden-hearted and miserable. At an adjoining table a par is in progress, singing and chattering and having a particularly good noisy time. A blonde at this table, loo over and sees Johnny. She moves her chair an inch backwar tilts it, so her face is nearly in Johnny's.
Hey, Lonely Heart -- what's the matter? Johnny makes a feeble attempt to call back in a croaking voice.
Happy New Year! The Blonde maneuvers herself a little nearer, crooks her through Johnny's.
All alone? C'mon over and join our party.
(desolately) Happy New Year!
Why're you so mad -- don't you feel good?
I feel fine.

C'mon, han'some, we got champagne! (she starts pulling at Johnny's arm, and turns to her companions) Look what I found! A poor little lamb lost in the storm -- alone and neglected. A chorus of hilarious greetings from the people at the ta with invitations to join them and have a drink. Johnny is resisting the efforts to make him take a seat at their ta when Jane rushes up, wild-eyed, panicky.
-- as Jane grabs hold of Johnny.
(hysterically) Johnny! Come quick! The baby! Johnny rises, alarmed.
Something's the matter with the baby! They rush out frantic, and we
CAMERA PULLS BACK, and we see now that printed above the word AMBULANCE is printed also

The ambulance is lined up at the curb. Out of the sounds the New Year's Eve revelry back of this comes the startin of an ambulance siren. CAMERA PULLS BACK FARTHER as the ambulance pulls away from the curb and with the noise of siren increasing, starts away. At the same time the ambulance starts away we see a taxi pull in to take the place of the departing ambulance. As comes to a stop with a grinding of brakes, from it emerge Johnny and Jane. Fear-stricken, they look after the depar ambulance, then rush over to Doctor Healy and Mrs. Mason stand at the curb. Doctor Healy carries his satchel.
(to Mrs. Mason frantically, looking back from the ambulance) Mother! The baby! Was that --?
(to the doctor) Doctor Healy, what is it? Jane's face is agonized. Doctor Healy hesitates, looks fr her to Johnny, hating what he has to tell them:
(gently -- sympathetically Pneumonia!
(a moan of anguish) Oh... Over the stricken face of Jane and Johnny we hear sounds laughter and yelling and cries of "Happy New Year."
-- with the words: ST. FRANCIS' HOSPITAL.

CAMERA PULLS BACK, and we see Johnny pacing up and down i front of the door. He too wears his evening clothes of th night before. The door opens and Doctor Healy comes out. Johnny comes quickly up to him.
(his voice trembling) Doctor Healy --
Come into the office a minute. He takes Johnny's arm and leads him into an office adjoin the laboratory.
Doctor Healy enters with Johnny.
Sit down, my boy. He indicates a chair by the desk. Johnny sits down. Docto Healy goes to the desk but doesn't sit.
You'd better get your wife.
Now, Doctor, if it's bad news I don't want her to know about it. She just couldn't stand it -- but you can tell me, Doctor.

(speaks with deep regret) Your baby has type nine Pneumoccocus with a streptoccocus complication. And I'm sorry to say that the congestion is increasing. Now, there's a serum -- a new one -- it's worked out in some cases. Without it, we don't stand a chance. With it, well, perhaps we have a ghost of a chance.  We must get some of that serum as soon as possible. Every hour counts. I don't know whether we can locate any of it in the city or not. I'm going to check up on that right away. Johnny gets to his feet and grabs the doctor by the arm.
(strangled voice) Doctor -- please don't tell my wife --
(gently) I won't. (picks up the phone -- speaks into it) Give me the City Health Department.
The lights are lighted. A young pharmacist in white jacke is talking over telephone.
(into telephone) All the type 9 serum has been sent to Salt Lake. Why don't you try Johns Hopkins in Baltimore?
A woman in laboratory smock talking over phone:
Sorry -- we shipped all we had for the epidemic in Salt Lake City.
Another man over phone:
Yes, the epidemic is under control here in Salt Lake, and we can spare six 20 c.c. vials, but how are you going to get it out of here in this storm?
Johnny is ringing the doorbell and banging on the knocker the same time.

Simon, the butler, comes to the door and opens it a littl to peer out at the midnight intruder. There is a blast of wind and rain as the door is shoved open and Johnny force his way into the hall. He is rain-drenched, dishevelled a almost hysterical with panic.
(breathless, panting) I've got to see Judge Doolittle right away!
At this hour of the morning?
You'll have to wake him up!
(frowning at this sacrilege) Oh -- I couldn't do that.
You've got to! He knows me -- I work for him. I've got to see him!
I'm sorry, but Judge Doolittle would never allow me to -- Johnny suddenly shoves the butler violently to one side starts up the stairs on the run.
As Johnny runs up toward the sleeping quarters above.
(alarmed and indignant) Say, there!... Wait! Wait!... You mustn't do that!... Where're you going? Simon starts up after Johnny.

The room is dark. Judge Doolittle is asleep in the four-p bed. Through the partly open transom we see the light go on in the hall and hear the commotion made by Johnny who is try to locate Judge Doolittle's room. He has opened a door an we hear him slam it closed.

You mustn't do this!... This is outrageous! The door in background is flung open and Johnny appears. light from the hallway helps him find the hall switch in room and he pushes it. The room lights up. Johnny starts toward the bed. The figure of the frightened butler appea in the open doorway in the b.g.
The judge is a heavy sleeper and the turning on of the li hasn't awakened him. Johnny comes into Shot. In the backg Simon waits, open-mouthed.
Judge Doolittle -- Doolittle stirs but doesn't waken. Johnny repeats, louder
Judge Doolittle!  He bends down and shakes the sleeping man.
Come on -- wake up! WAKE UP!
He awakes and peers owlishly upward, squinting through on eye.
Judge, I'm sorry to wake you like this --

Doolittle throws the blanket off and is revealed in pajam He swings over and sits on the edge of the bed, reaches f his glasses on the night table, puts them on and glares u at Johnny, anger creeping through his drowsiness.
What... what is this?
I've got to talk to you right now --
Are you drunk?
My kid's in the hospital -- he's got pneumonia -- Doolittle cups his hand to his ear, trying to hear; looks around for his acousticon.

(not hearing) You must be drunk waking me up in the middle of the night like this -- it's outrageous! Never heard of such a thing! Johnny realizes Doolittle isn't hearing him. He looks aro spots the judge's acousticon on the night table and reach for it.
Mason, if this is your way of celebrating the New Year -- Johnny shoves the acousticon into Doolittle's hand.
(harshly) Put it on! Doolittle puts it on, outraged.
(glaring) Now Mason, you listen to me --
(shouts) No! -- You listen to me! When you asked me to take a cut I took it -- but I shouldn't have. Because that's the reason the baby has to sleep in the dining room and --
(beginning to doubt Johnny's sanity) What're you talking about?
My baby's in the hospital, dying of pneumonia!
(motions with acousticon) What?
(shouts) Dying!... Dying!... Can't you understand that?
Dying?
Yes, my baby!
(now comprehending) Your baby? Well, (his rage melts) Why didn't you get in touch with me sooner? I'm terribly sorry. (he gets out of bed and puts on his robe)

I don't need sympathy -- I need serum! There isn't any in New York -- and there's none anywhere near here -- and they finally located some in Salt Lake City -- and that's two thousand miles away and every hour counts! (he is almost sobbing the words out now)
(with utmost sympathy) Now, Mason -- be calm --
I can't be calm -- I'll never be calm till I get the serum. And the only way to get it here is to fly it --
(excitedly) Certainly!... Fly it!... Of course!
But there's a terrific storm over Utah -- all planes are grounded -- if there's just one thing we could do --
(grabs hold of Johnny's arms) Now, Mason -- get hold of yourself!... I know how you feel, but get hold of yourself! Suppose the planes are grounded -- Why can't you put it on one of the fast trains?

But we can't. I told you hours count -- every minute counts. It'd be too late. We need a plane from Salt Lake and we've got one but the pilot wants five thousand dollars to fly it to New York -- (his voice breaks) And Judge, I didn't have anyone else to turn to -- Doolittle interrupts him with a loud shout.
(looks off scene) SIMON! Well, what're you standing there for? The butler comes into the scene.
My check book!... Get me my check book! CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS as Simon scurries to secretary.
And get me a pen! Quick! One that will write! And find out where the nearest telegraph office is! Simon scurries out of the room.

(he goes to Johnny whose head is buried in his hands -- patting Johnny on the shoulder) You should have gotten in touch with me sooner -- but don't you worry about that serum; we'll have it here and in plenty of time too! As Johnny looks up at Judge Doolittle pitifully and gratefully, with Doolittle's hand still on his shoulder, hold a minute, then

The sock flops crazily in the wind. CAMERA MOVES PAST IT DOWN, revealing a stretch of snowy ground with building o airport office below. The circular beacon of the landing field is dimly visible through the storm. AS CAMERA MOVES DOWN we come over the airport office structure which has large lettering covering the roof area. The lettering is partially obliterated by wind-swept snow, but as CAMERA M CLOSER we can make it out: SALT LAKE CITY.

Yeah, Mr. Mason -- the serum's here and the money's here too -- and I could certainly use the dough. But the weather's gotten so bad it's impossible to take off -- (listens a minute) What can I do? -- CAMERA MOVES BACK to take in Collins, Conway and a couple others standing by, listening. Hatton turns an eloquent l of despair on them as he listens.

I know how you feel -- I'm married myself and I've got a couple of kids -- but I got to think of them too. My wife won't let me -- she says if I go she won't be here when I get back -- if I get back. (he puts his hand over the receiver and remarks to the group around him; plaintively) What do you do with a guy like that?

Let me talk to him. (he takes the phone from Hatton's hands and speaks into it;  belligerently) Now listen you -- what do you think this is -- a suicide club? You can't expect anybody in his right mind to fly a plane on a night like this -- especially an old crate with whiskers. Why don't you -- (he listens a moment and we see his truculence gradually melting) Sure... That's tough... we'd certainly like to help you -- ain't there no other place you could get some of the stuff? Maybe in a few hours, when the weather clears up -- (he listens a moment -- his expression changes. He puts his hand over the receiver and turns to the group around him) (in an awed voice) Gee, the guy's crying -- (picks up receiver) Now wait a minute, buddy... take it easy... Suppose we -- maybe I -- hold the wire! (he puts his hand over receiver and turns to the group behind him; helplessly He just won't take No for an answer. (hesitates, then speaks to Hatton) Jim, could I borrow your plane?
Are you nuts?
You know how it is -- you've got kids of your own. Suppose you was in his place --
I can't let you have my plane. I've got no insurance on it -- I couldn't get any --
(in phone) Hold it a minute -- keep your shirt on -- (to Hatton) I'll give you half the money if you'll loan me the crate.
Suppose you crack it up --
Then you can keep the whole five -- I won't need it.
I think you're crazy. But, all right -- if you want to.
(speaking into phone) Okay, buddy -- relax.
Standing at the frost covered window, Hatton, Collins and couple of others.
Do you think he'll ever get off the ground with all that gas?

Well, I did -- going to Honolulu -- Hatton rubs off some of the frost to clear a space on the pane and they peer through at the field. Through the bliz with the beacon lights circling the field, we dimly make Conway's plane. It taxies across the field and takes off the storm. The men listen to the dying sound of the plane's motors. Hatton shrugs and turns to Collins.
I can't say I like that kind of money --  but it looks like I'll be in five grand before morning.

The corridor is quite dark, except for such light as may come in from laboratory or perhaps one open door somewher in corridor. Doctor Healy comes out of the baby's room, s Jane coming toward him as he closes the door. He glances down hall and sees in the b.g. the dim figure of a man wheeling something toward the baby's room. He turns quick to Jane, maneuvering so she cannot see what is coming dow the corridor. Jane looks imploringly at the doctor's face.
He's all right -- he's holding his own nicely.
May I go in and see him?
I don't think you'd better -- not just now.
(getting panicky) Why, doctor? Why don't you want me to see him?
Now, don't worry -- it's just that --

(with tinge of hysteria) Then why don't you want me to see him? She starts to brush past the doctor forcibly, when she st seeing that the man with the wheelbarrow who has come up behind the doctor has opened the door of the baby's room. he does, a light from the baby's room reveals the cylinde of oxygen which he has been wheeling.
The light from the room falling on the cylinder in such a manner as to bring out vividly the word "OXYGEN" printed it.
The shock of seeing the oxygen is the trigger that unloos the pent-up emotion in Jane.

(hysterically) You're lying to me, Doctor! The baby's worse; that's why you ordered the oxygen. She reaches for the door-knob and the doctor stops her, grabbing hold of her. Mrs. Mason comes into the scene fro the waiting room. The doctor and Mrs. Mason try to soothe Jane and her hysteria mounts. The doctor takes hold of on of Jane's arms and Mrs. Mason the other.
Jane, dear -- Jane -- please...
The oxygen's only to help him till the serum gets here.
(hysterically) You're lying to me! CAMERA TRUCKS with them as they lead her forcibly away fr the baby's room toward the waiting room.
I want you to lie down and rest -- I'll give you something to make you sleep. Will you do that for me?
(hysterically) Oh, Doctor Healy -- I couldn't! Please don't make me! They stop at the entrance of the waiting room. Jane takes hold of herself and with a powerful effort, controls her  hysteria.
I'm sorry, Doctor -- I'm all right now. (pleadingly) When can I see him?

In a little while. He exits back to baby's room; CAMERA PANS with Jane as sh goes to the window seat, sinks to the floor and looks out the beating rain of the night. Mrs. Mason comes into the Shot and looks pityingly down at the wretched, forlorn fi
(after a second or two) If my baby dies, I want to die, too.

(sympathetically) I know, dear, I know... But you mustn't feel that way. You mustn't let John know you feel that way... He loves the baby too... (there is a very slight choke in her throat) Almost as much as he loves you.
Poor Johnny... He'll be so lonely if the baby -- She can't bring herself to say, "dies."

(simply) He'll have you, Jane... And you'll have him... (Jane makes no comment. Mrs. Mason continues) And you can't be lonely... either of you... as long as you have each other... (she looks away) Do you know when you're really lonely? It's when you have no one to share  things with... not even a loss... (she can't go further in her revelation)

(turns slowly -- seeing her mother-in-law for the first time) Oh, Mother -- you're lonely... aren't you? Mrs. Mason turns away. There is a silence. Jane goes to h sympathetically, almost forgetting her own grief for a mo

I wasn't -- always -- a bitter old woman... I wasn't always a pest and a nuisance... (she breaks) ...not when I had someone to share things with. Jane takes her into her arms, and now Jane comforts her, whose front breaks, and who sobs against Jane.
(muffled) And now the baby... Oh, my baby's baby...

(the tears rolling down her cheeks) Oh, Mother, Mother... And on a tableau of Jane devotedly and heart-brokenly comforting her old mother-in-law, whose head is on Jane's shoulder, Jane's arm around her, we
The plane is making its way over a vista of snow-capped mountain peaks.
The storm seems to be increasing in violence causing the ship to roll from side to side.

He is worried, reaches for the radio transmitter and yell into the mouthpiece. His voice cannot be heard over the r of the motor and the howling wind. Conway shakes his head, getting over that he gets no resp His radio is evidently out of commission. He takes off th head-set -- glances at the instrument board.
Needle registers 13,500 feet.
He looks at serum package, takes off his glove and feels package to make sure it hasn't frozen.
It is marked "RUSH - AVOID FREEZING." Conway's hand feels the package.
Satisfied that the serum is okay he starts to write on a that is strapped to his leg between knee and thigh.
Conway writes: "6:40 A. M. Radio dead. Fighting for altitude. Terrific d draft. Forc--" A sudden lurch of the plane snaps the lead in the pencil.
As he grabs the quivering joystick -- fights vainly to co the plane.
Starts to lose altitude.
Needle going down.
A thrilling shot of the plane going down.
Fighting joystick. He looks over side of plane.
Diving at rugged snow covered cliffs, the ground appearin to come closer and closer.
Struggling to control the plane. The snow and mist gettin heavier.
The wheels touch the ground and for an instant it looks a if all were over. With a roar of the motor the plane zoom up.
It fails to gain altitude and continues down and down unt it is completely lost in the swirling snow and mist. Hold snow-filled screen a moment.
Rain is beating against the window behind him. He is talk into his instrument.
Denver calling Commercial NC 24.  Come in, Conway. (ANXIOUSLY)

Come in! (waits -- no answer comes -- he speaks again with increasing anxiety) Can't you read me, Conway? Can't you read me? Come in, Conway. (still no answer; turns dial; shakes his head in despair -- in dead, hopeless voice) Denver calling Newark. Do you read me, Newark?

-- at his instrument board. CAMERA DRAWS BACK to reveal behind the Newark chief opera the chief of operators at Newark airport (Superintendent) the assistant radio operator, Judge Doolittle and Johnny. The two latter are listening with suppressed excitement.
(coming from instrument) Still can't contact Conway. Storm increasing over the Rockies. Denver.
He registers apprehension as he listens.
Worried, he unfolds his arms.
(quietly, in flat voice, controlling his fears) Send out an emergency to all stations. Stand by to contact Conway.
North Platte, Nebraska calling Conway -- Commercial NC 24. Do you read me?
Conway NC 24. This is Omaha. Do you read me, Conway?
Chicago calling Commercial NC 24... Conway can you read me? Can't you answer, Conway?

One ranger is in uniform and is at the telephone. Another gazing out a window in b.g., against which snow is striki The latter is peering through binoculars. A pair of dripp skiis stand against the walls beside the man at the phone
(into phone; shakes his head) No, we haven't seen or heard a plane all day. Sorry, but there's no use sending searching parties out in this blizzard.
Reading: "All Hope Gone For Mercy Plane."

The rain has stopped, but it is a dark dreary day and the lights of the hospital are turned on. A nurse sits by the bedside. OPEN ON CLOSE SHOT OF THE BABY in his small bed covered w the oxygen tent. He breathes with great difficulty. CAMER PANS AROUND to show Dr. Healy crossing the room with his stethoscope in his hand, making his way to the bed. CAMER FOLLOWS DR. HEALY until he passes in front of Jane, then HOLDS ON JANE and we see her looking fixedly at the small bed, stark pain in her eyes. Sister Madelaine stands besi her. BIG HEAD CLOSE UP - DOCTOR HEALY - the earphones over his ears. As he listens gravely to the irregular heartbeats of the baby; and we hear them faintly on the sound track.
Her hand goes to her breast in a mute gesture of agony as she watches. In a low voice she gives expression to the o thought that has been racking through her head for hours.
(a tired whisper) Oh, if there was just something I could do... If there was just something... Sister Madelaine moves closer, puts her hand gently on Ja shoulder.
(simply) There is... Come with me. She takes Jane's arm. CAMERA TRUCKS WITH THEM as they lea the room and start down the corridor together.
Sister Madelaine opens the doors. Jane looks in and sees chapel.
(turns to Sister Madelaine) Sister Madelaine, I'm not a Catholic --
(shakes her head slightly) That doesn't matter. Jane steps into the chapel. Sister Madelaine softly close the chapel doors behind her. CAMERA TRUCKS IN FRONT of Jane as she walks down toward t altar.

Taking in the altar -- the lit candles, the figure of Jes Jane comes into Shot and looks uncertainly about. She stu the figure of Jesus a moment in silence. She hesitates, t sinks to her knees before the figure and with her head bo mutters to herself, shaking her head. She lifts her face the figure.
Shooting down from above and behind the silhouetted figur of Jesus, only Jane's face lighted by the candlelight.
(stumbling to find the right words) You know how much he means to Johnny

and me... we've only had him such a little while... Oh God, dear, dear God, please... We do want to see him grow up and be a man. Please help our little baby... we love him so... he's so small and helpless... he can't do anything for himself... and we can't seem to do anything. for him... (she clasps her hands and speaks imploringly) Please -- Please -- Please...
Starting with shot only of gray fog and clouds and sound roaring plane motor. Then plane emerges from behind cloud into scene.
He is worried -- reaches for a map and with a flash light tries to find something he can recognize on the map --
With Conway's flash light shining on it.

He is frantic, realizing he is lost. He puts the map and flash light away and looks over side of plane to see if t is a hole in the clouds that he might get through -- then almost instinctively, nervously reaches for a cigarette. Suddenly a few drops of oil spatter the windshield of the plane. He peers over the side, alarmed, and oil sprays on his goggles. As he pushes his goggles back and wipes his face,
With a cloud of smoke pouring out behind. The plane is catching fire.
Frantically pulls out his flash light, prepares to bail o picks up the box of serum and sticks it under his jacket and jumps.
Parachute and plane falling. The plane now spurting flame The parachute disappears into the fog.
Doctor Healy, showing the signs of strain and weariness, stands in the office drinking from a coffee cup. A unifor nurse stands before him.
Shall I order another tank of oxygen, Doctor?
(shrugs in despair) If the serum isn't here in a couple of hours... He turns toward the door as he hears sound of footsteps i the corridor.
The defeated figure of Johnny passes the doorway. His coa collar is turned up around his ears.
Lying stretched out, with pillows under her head, on the window seat. She tosses her head slowly and restlessly. W hold on her long enough to allow for Johnny's walk down t hall.
Johnny enters. Jane turns, sees him.
(almost listlessly) Hello, Johnny.
Hello, Jane. (he crosses over and kneels beside her)
Looking at Johnny.
Looking at Jane.
Johnny gently strokes her hair. He speaks with a strange, new-found serenity.
We'll always be together, Jane -- no matter what happens -- like this, always. He continues stroking her hair, and we hold on this a mom then.

head_text.subj: THE PARACHUTE TANGLED UP IN THE

text: CAMERA PANS DOWN the tattered chute to the body of Conway limply sprawled out on the wet ground. We hold for a mome CAMERA MOVES UP to a CLOSER SHOT. We hold a moment on his motionless figure, then we see the body stir.

His face is scratched and filthy. He opens his eyes, lift himself up with a grimace of pain. He stares for a moment his left foot, then starts to disengage the harness of th chute. He remembers something and sticks his right hand frantically on the inside of his coat. His hand comes out with the package of serum. It is safe. He manages a grin through his pain and puts it back inside his coat. He loo around, tries to get to his feet, and realizes he can't w His leg is broken. CAMERA TRUCKS WITH HIM as he starts to crawl along the muddy field through the fog.
Crawling along the field. As his body is lost in the fog,
The farmhouse stands alone. Conway's figure is dimly seen his knees knocking at the door. From o.s., the sound of a dog barking.  A light goes on in an upstairs window.

Conway on his knees before the door, pounding on it with knuckles. From o.s., the sound of the dog barking. The do opens and a sleepy, bewildered farmer with an overcoat ov his full-length underwear in which he has undoubtedly bee sleeping is seen. Behind him, carrying a kerosene lamp, i the farmer's wife with a shabby robe over her nightgown.
Who are you? What do you want?
I'm hurt. Will you help me?
Mercy sakes alive. Farmer and his wife go to Conway, half lift him up and dr him over the threshold.
Farmer and his wife helping Conway into the room. They st frightened, and bewildered at the strange figure they hav let in out of the night.
What is it -- what's happened?
Never mind that -- what place is this?
Liberty Corners.
Where's that?
Thirty-five miles from New York. Suddenly Conway sways and his eyes close. He falls to the floor in a dead faint.

Well, for mercy sakes alive. The farmer drops to his knees beside Conway. He turns the unconscious form over and looks down into Conway's face. Suddenly the farmer catches sight of the package of serum which is protruding from the open front of Conway's flyin suit. The farmer pulls the package out and stares at it.

(reading the label) St. Francis Hospital, New York City. Rush. The significance of the package dawns on him. He rises an hurries to the telephone. The phone is an old fashioned one, used only in rural districts. The farmer turns the handle and the bell rings the signal for the operator; he then takes down the recei and speaks.
(into phone) Hello -- hello -- operator, I want the St. Francis Hospital, New York City. (he glances toward the weird looking body of Conway, turns back to the phone) And reverse the charges.
The wrapping being torn off and the box opened, exposing vials of serum.
The name: DR. HEALY flashing on and off.
Holding the baby's wrist -- taking his pulse.
-- being filled with fluid.

The door bursts open and Johnny comes out, turns to look back into the baby's room for a moment, then starts off d the long corridor at a run. He reaches the door to the waiting room and throws it ope
Jane is sitting near the window, asleep, worn out with wo and strain. She hears Johnny coming in and wakes up with start. Jane looks at Johnny -- a silent question in her eyes.
(tenderly -- joyfully Happy New Year, darling. Jane only stares at him, then the significance of the wor strikes her. She goes into his arms.
(hysterically) Happy New Year -- Happy New Year -- Over her hysterical laughter,

Dr. Healy, Judge Doolittle, Ed Conway, the pilot who brou the serum. Conway's left leg is stiff and he leans on a c CAMERA PICKS UP our trio as the three lift their glasses and slug down their drinks, then set the empty glasses do on the bar.
(smacking his lips) Well, gentlemen, I guess four's about enough on a business day.
That's all very well, Joe -- but isn't it about time you bought one?
(flips open his coat) What's that?
(speaks into mouthpiece) Conway calling Doolittle...
We read first only the old firm name of:
CAMERA PANS DOWN to CLOSE UP the remainder of firm name w now reads:
And there are certain things, gentlemen, that I want distinctly understood.

CAMERA DRAWS BACK to reveal Johnny pacing before the two brothers. He is orating great guns. At his desk, Doolittl is seated, and standing behind him are several other memb of the staff, which include the hitherto nebulous, Messerschmidt, Hutch and the other Doolittle. They are al watching and listening to Johnny with the greatest respec and attention. It is obvious that Johnny is now the fair- haired boy of the firm.

Now, I called this meeting of all the partners in order to make my position clear once and for all. That before I accept your offer of partnership in the firm of -- INTERCUT CLOSE UPS of each member of the firm as Johnny c their names.

-- Doolittle -- Messerschmidt -- Doolittle -- Hutch -- and Carter, you must know that I consider the methods of this firm at the present time old-fashioned, self-satisfied, high-handed and thoroughly inefficient. Carter, who has been leaning against the wall, straighten up and addresses Doolittle.
It seems to me --
(sharply) Quiet!
And I demand that they be changed -- effective immediately. There is a loud knock on the door.
(frowns and calls out) Come in!
It opens and John Horace Mason, II, walks in on his own p An instant later, Jane and Mrs. Mason come in, bursting w news.
Excuse me, I hope we haven't interrupted anything important -- Johnny comes into scene, frowning.
Now, Jane --
Johnny, I know Judge Doolittle won't mind -- CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS as Judge Doolittle and the others, co into the scene.
We just couldn't wait --
We had to rush down the minute it happened!
What happened?
The baby can TALK! She drops down on her knees by the baby and takes hold of his shoulders.
(to the baby) They don't believe us! Come on, darling -- we'll prove it to them! The men in the office crowd around her.
-- beaming with pride.
The faces of the men behind Johnny. They wait expectantly
Show them, darling! Don't be afraid -- speak up -- say Daddy! Say Daddy -- please, darling -- say Daddy!
Looking coyly up at the group around him. He
(pleadingly) Say Daddy! D--D--D -- Daddy.
Just looking.
Say Daddy -- say Daddy --
Come on, Johnny. Say Daddy -- Say Daddy --
Ma-ma.
As they flip back their coats to hear better.
(together) What?
says nothing.
